# Biglaw Is Doomed If This Becomes A Trend
## Surprising no one, clients are increasingly refusing to pay for associates.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onSeptember 21, 2017 at 12:35 PMSeptember 22, 2017 at 10:59 AM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/biglaw-is-doomed-if-this-becomes-a-trend/&text=Biglaw%20Is%20Doomed%20If%20This%20Becomes%20A%20Trend)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/biglaw-is-doomed-if-this-becomes-a-trend/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/biglaw-is-doomed-if-this-becomes-a-trend/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The Biglaw financial model relies upon leverage, the fancy term for throwing armies of young associates at a matter and watching the profits funnel ever upward into the partnership coffers. While $2000/hour partners may [inspire a few headlines](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/2000-an-hour-lawyers-thats-one-way-to-fund-salary-increases/), multi-millionaires billing four figures aren’t nearly as lucrative as a couple of $180K associates grinding out 2400 hours at $400 an hour. This is how Biglaw stays big.

The fact that deep-pocketed clients are forking over — in substantial part — for these fresh-faced lawyers to get all their on-the-job training is just another perk of sitting on top of the Biglaw food chain.

But general counsel may have finally had enough of it. At least according to this [Am Law Daily report](http://www.americanlawyer.com/id=1202798363967/Pay-for-Associate-Hours-More-Companies-Say-No-Thanks/) on the recent SOLID Summit:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
At a Manhattan [conference on legal innovation](https://www.cowenevents.com/) this month, Mark Smolik, the general counsel of DHL Supply Chain Americas, had a message for the law firm representatives in his audience.

“Sorry, law firms. You spend on the training,” Smolik said. “I cannot afford to pay your associates $325 an hour.”

Instead, Smolik told the group, he’d go straight to the source for young legal talent, and “pick them up right out of law school.”

Biglaw already faced an associate demand problem as document review vendors have chipped away at the need for the legions of litigation minions of the past, while review technology — [for example, Kira Systems](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/artificial-confusion-the-overblown-threat-of-artificial-intelligence/) — will reduce the need for transactional headcount. If clients rob firms of the profit motive to hire young lawyers, then just how much business sense does it make to be Biglaw? That overhead doesn’t pay itself.

That said, we’ve heard clients talk about [drawing a line in the sand](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/some-clients-are-super-pissed-about-associate-raises/) over paying for associate salaries before. At the end of the day, Cravath still got its pound of flesh. But it’s one thing to complain about fees and another to take the bull by the horns and hire young lawyers directly. With in-house departments using their own headcount to handle more matters, the Am Law 50 may still manage to collect some associate billables on complex matters. A solid brand can open even the stingiest wallets.

But the rest of the legal industry might find all their leverage blink out of existence.

### [ How Will Walgreens’ Expansion Into Specialty Pharmacy Affect The Industry? ](https://medcitynews.com/2024/04/walgreens-specialty-pharmacy-drugs/)
Walgreens announced that it is expanding its specialty pharmacy offerings. Experts think that this move could yield several strategic benefits, given the higher profit margins associated with specialty medications compared to traditional drugs. They also think Walgreens’ move could lead to greater competition, consolidation, and innovation within the broader pharmacy industry.

# Legal Industry Diversity & Inclusion: Top Issues For 2022
## Several upcoming programs from PLI will provide useful insights into the current state of diversity and inclusion in the legal industry and what’s being done to make progress.
By STEPHANIE WILKINS  
onJune 16, 2022 at 2:14 PMJune 16, 2022 at 1:59 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/legal-industry-diversity-inclusion-top-issues-for-2022/&text=Legal%20Industry%20Diversity%20&%20Inclusion:%20Top%20Issues%20For%202022)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/legal-industry-diversity-inclusion-top-issues-for-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/legal-industry-diversity-inclusion-top-issues-for-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Efforts to increase diversity and inclusion in the legal industry have been gaining steam in recent years, with the spotlight increasingly focused on the specific steps lawyers and firms can take to make improvements. 

Several upcoming programs from PLI will provide useful insights into the current state of diversity and inclusion in the legal industry and what’s being done to make progress. The first is a one-day program, [Diversity & Inclusion in Law Practice 2022](https://www.pli.edu/programs/diversity--inclusion-in-law-practice?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), with a panel of experts reviewing diversity and inclusion in the legal profession today and discussing practical policies and best practices you can put into action in your own workplace.

Topics to be covered include: 

- Recognizing what needs to be done (both individually and institutionally) to build an inclusive workplace
- Identifying proven practices and policies you can implement to advance diversity and inclusion initiatives in your law office 
- Learning how to create mentoring circles that extend beyond your law office to counter diverse attorneys’ professional isolation and support retention efforts
This program is ideal for all members of the legal profession who are concerned about diversity, equity, and inclusion in the workplace, regardless of their role or the nature of their organization. [Register](https://www.pli.edu/programs/diversity--inclusion-in-law-practice?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2) today. 

Another program, [Unconscious Bias: How to Recognize and Disrupt Its Impact on Your Decision-Making Process](https://www.pli.edu/programs/unconscious-bias--how-to-recognize-and-disrupt-its-impact-on-your-decision-making-process?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2), is a one-hour briefing designed to shed light on unconscious bias (also known as implicit bias) and how it might impact your decisions at work.

Everyone has unconscious biases, and this session will offer ways to identify yours, and how they may surface at work. Topics to be discussed include: 

- Defining unconscious bias and explaining its impact on decision-making
- Examples of law office unconscious bias and strategies for disruption
- Defining microaggressions/micro-inequities and common examples of how they occur in the legal profession
- Strategies to disrupt unconscious bias in your decision-making process
- Strategies to eliminate microaggressions in the legal profession 
[Register](https://www.pli.edu/programs/unconscious-bias--how-to-recognize-and-disrupt-its-impact-on-your-decision-making-process?t=live&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2) today to learn more about this critical topic.

Finally, for an in-depth look at implicit bias — with an interactive twist — check out PLI’s on-demand program, [Diversity and Inclusion in the Legal Profession: Addressing Implicit Bias](https://www.pli.edu/programs/diversity-and-inclusion-in-the-legal-profession?t=ondemand&p=340629&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2). 

This two-hour program takes learners behind the scenes at the production of a TV drama about a fictional law firm, inviting participants to help make choices around casting, scripts, and storylines to help improve diversity. Through role-playing and goal-setting, participants can gain an understanding of the issues limiting progress on DEI in law firms, and learn ways to address them and create positive change.

[Register and start learning today](https://www.pli.edu/programs/diversity-and-inclusion-in-the-legal-profession?t=ondemand&p=340629&tCode=CNS2_ATL01&utm_source=ATL01&utm_medium=DISPLAY&utm_campaign=CNS2). 

####Topics

# Associates At This Firm Are REALLY Pissed About Their Bonuses...
## Associates at this firm say morale is terrible.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 16, 2016 at 12:12 PMDecember 16, 2016 at 3:09 PM
8
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associates-at-this-firm-are-really-pissed-about-their-bonuses/&text=Associates%20At%20This%20Firm%20Are%20REALLY%20Pissed%20About%20Their%20Bonuses…)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associates-at-this-firm-are-really-pissed-about-their-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associates-at-this-firm-are-really-pissed-about-their-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
… and they haven’t even received them yet.

Earlier this month, we asked readers to [get in touch with us](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/so-who-is-pissed-about-their-bonuses/) if they were angry about their bonuses. This week, we received a slew of complaints from associates at Irell & Manella, the elite California firm that was once known for its market-beating bonuses. Unfortunately, in recent years, the firm’s bonus bounty — while still better than the standard market match — has been smaller than usual. In fact, since 2011, when the firm paid [double the Cravath scale](https://abovethelaw.com/2012/01/associate-bonus-watch-irell-whacks-cravath-again/), Irell’s bonus payouts have shrunk in size each year. Considering the fact that many associates could have jumped ship to Hueston Hennigan, a firm that announced [incredibly generous bonuses](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/12/associate-bonus-watch-still-more-boutique-bonus-bounty/) this week, on top of a [spring bonus](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/associate-bonus-watch-spring-bonuses-is-this-real-life/) paid earlier this year, those who remained at Irell are understandably upset. Here’s a gripe we received from one Irell associate:

Associate morale at Irell is terrible. The firm seems to be squeezing out more associates. Meanwhile, across the way we see Hueston Hennigan flourishing and richly rewarding their associates. People around here are kind of depressed.

Everyone is hoping the firm will step up and be competitive with Hueston Hennigan, but no one thinks it will happen. For years, Irell was dominant on the compensation front. People came to Irell because Irell could not be beat compensation wise. That is no longer true.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
A second Irell tipster contacted us with the following information: “All the associates feel worn out and let down. The firm hasn’t even announced the MEETING to announce bonuses yet.” Given that Irell usually announces its bonuses before Christmas, that means there’s going to be a meeting next week, or the firm is going to break with tradition and keep its associates waiting until after the holiday.

What do Irell associates think will happen when their bonuses are finally announced?

The consensus among associates seems to be they will do the same they did last year. The firm usually comes in over Cravath, but considering the Hueston Hennigan bonuses, I think people are going to be disappointed anyway.

For the record, this is what the Irell bonuses looked like [last year](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/12/associate-bonus-watch-same-as-it-ever-was/) (with the market bonus, i.e., Cravath, indicated parenthetically). We’ve updated this for the 2016 scale:

###Sponsored
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Class of 2016: 20K (15K)
Class of 2015: 20K (15K)
Class of 2014: 30K (25K)
Class of 2013: 60K (50K)
Class of 2012: 75K (65K)
Class of 2011: 90K (80K)
Class of 2010: 105K (90K)
Class of 2009: 115K (100K)
Class of 2008: 120K (100K)

If and when Irell pays out the exact same bonus scale as it did last year, associates who opted to remain with the firm are going to feel pretty hurt. We think that this Irell associate really hit the nail on the head with her commentary about bonuses:

No one wants to feel like the associates who deserted to HH are doing better than the associates who decided to stay and be loyal. It’s personal. The people who stayed, they want to feel like they made the right choice and that the firm recognizes and appreciates them. That’s where it is lacking — a lot of associates here don’t feel appreciated.

A final Irell associate described the firm’s partnership as “tone deaf,” “blind to outside perception,” and “out of touch.” Will those in charge of the firm even care that its associates are so upset? We certainly hope so, but if not, we have a feeling that a [certain boutique law firm](https://www.hueston.com/careers) would be happy to harbor some additional Irell & Manella refugees.

So who else out there knows the holidays won’t be happy (at least money-wise)? Drop us an [email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com) and let us know — we’d love to hear your complaints. Funny, biting, or otherwise interesting responses may be published anonymously here on Above the Law.

text:
[  ](/)	[Home](/) | [Archive](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/archive/) | [RSS](/feed/) | [Twitter](https://www.twitter.com/howappealing) | [Contact](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

	

Thursday, September 14, 2017
“Here’s what Supreme Court Justice Sonia Sotomayor had to say at Clemson”: Georgie Silvarole of The Anderson (S.C.) Independent Mail has [this report](http://www.independentmail.com/story/news/2017/09/14/supreme-court-justice-sonia-sotomayor-clemson/665274001/).

Posted at [11:58 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72797) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“‘Think like a lawyer’ US Supreme Court Justice Alito says at USC law school dedication”: John Monk of The State of Columbia, South Carolina has [this report](http://www.thestate.com/news/local/crime/article173338521.html).

Posted at [11:57 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72796) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Advice for appellate lawyers doing their first Third Circuit case”: Matthew Stiegler has [this post](http://ca3blog.com/writing/advice-for-appellate-lawyers-doing-their-first-third-circuit-case/) at his “CA3blog.”

Posted at [11:07 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72795) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Child porn conviction upheld in youth sexting case”: Jim Camden of The Spokesman-Review of Spokane, Washington has [an article](http://www.spokesman.com/stories/2017/sep/14/child-porn-conviction-upheld-in-youth-sexting-case/) that begins, “A Spokane youth who texted a picture of his genitals to a woman can be convicted under the state laws against child pornography even though he is the child involved, the Washington Supreme Court said Thursday.”

Rachel La Corte of The Associated Press has a report headlined “[Court: Washington state teen who sent image committed crime](http://www.yakimaherald.com/news/state_news/court-washington-state-teen-who-sent-image-committed-crime/article_c3f294f3-4fe3-5dca-91eb-ad8176b55409.html).”

And Cyrus Farivar of Ars Technica has an article headlined “[Teen sends dick pic to 22-year-old woman, now he’s a child pornographer; Washington Supreme Court: Child porn laws apply even if perp, victim are the same](https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/09/teen-sends-dick-pic-to-22-year-old-now-hes-a-child-pornographer/).”

My earlier coverage of [today’s Washington State Supreme Court ruling](https://www.courts.wa.gov/opinions/pdf/936099.pdf) can be [accessed here](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/091417.html#072774).

Posted at [10:09 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72794) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Supreme Court Term Preview: The American Constitution Society for Law and Policy hosted a discussion on the 2017-18 Supreme Court term.” C-SPAN has posted online [the video](https://www.c-span.org/video/?434059-1/supreme-court-term-preview) of [this event](https://events.acslaw.org/rsvp/Event_RSVP?id=a0Y0f00000FcwZBEAZ) from earlier today.

Posted at [10:02 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72793) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“After Justice Department yields, federal judge still not ready to toss Arpaio conviction”: Megan Cassidy of The Arizona Republic has [this report](http://www.azcentral.com/story/news/local/phoenix/2017/09/14/after-justice-department-yields-federal-judge-still-not-ready-toss-arpaio-conviction/668019001/).

And Chris Geidner of BuzzFeed News reports that “[Judge Questions If Court Can Toss Out Joe Arpaio’s Conviction After Trump’s Pardon](https://www.buzzfeed.com/chrisgeidner/judge-questions-if-court-can-toss-out-joe-arpaios).”

Posted at [9:10 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72792) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Judge Posner, Uncensored: ‘I Don’t Really Care What People Think’; The recently retired Richard Posner has lost none of his famous candor.” David Lat has [this post](http://abovethelaw.com/2017/09/judge-posner-uncensored-i-dont-really-care-what-people-think/) at “Above the Law.” And [Posner’s newest book](https://www.amazon.com/Reforming-Federal-Judiciary-Televising-Arguments/dp/1976014794/) is now available for purchase.

Posted at [8:57 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72791) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“South Dakota tax law headed to Supreme Court”: Jonathan Ellis and Dana Ferguson of The Argus Leader of Sioux Falls, South Dakota have [an article](http://www.argusleader.com/story/news/2017/09/14/u-s-supreme-court-next-stop-south-dakota-internet-tax-case/665399001/) that begins, “The South Dakota Supreme Court has ruled that the state cannot force out-of-state retailers to collect sales tax, setting up a possible appeal to the U.S. Supreme Court that will have national implications.”

Jef Feeley of Bloomberg News reports that “[Internet Tax Ruling Worth Billions Poised for Supreme Court Review](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-14/south-dakota-internet-tax-ruling-tees-issue-up-for-high-court).”

The Associated Press reports that “[South Dakota court rejects law aimed at online sales taxes](http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/U/US_SALES_TAX_LAWSUIT?SITE=AP&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT).”

And in commentary, online at Medium, law professor [Daniel Hemel](https://www.law.uchicago.edu/faculty/hemel) has a post titled “[The Common Law and the Commerce Clause: There’s a strong argument for overturning the Supreme Court’s Quill precedent based on . . . Supreme Court precedent](https://medium.com/whatever-source-derived/the-common-law-and-the-commerce-clause-b41e0f471452).”

You can access yesterday’s ruling of the [Supreme Court of South Dakota](http://ujs.sd.gov/Supreme_Court/default.aspx) at [this link](http://ujs.sd.gov/uploads/sc/opinions/28160.pdf).

Posted at [8:45 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72790) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“A Federal Judge Was Ordered To Take A Mental Health Exam; He Refused — And Is Suing Over It”: Zoe Tillman of BuzzFeed News has [this report](https://www.buzzfeed.com/zoetillman/a-federal-judge-was-ordered-to-take-a-mental-health-exam-he).

Posted at [5:58 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72789) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Trump Humiliated Jeff Sessions After Mueller Appointment”: Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman of The New York Times have [this report](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/14/us/politics/jeff-sessions-trump.html).

Posted at [5:54 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72788) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Supreme Court by the Numbers: Kicking Off the 2017 Term.” Kimberly S. Robinson of Bloomberg BNA has [this report](https://bol.bna.com/supreme-court-by-the-numbers-kicking-off-the-2017-term/).

Posted at [5:50 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72787) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Democrats Could Soon Lose Leverage In The Fight Over Trump’s Judicial Nominees”: Zoe Tillman of BuzzFeed News has [this report](https://www.buzzfeed.com/zoetillman/democrats-could-soon-lose-leverage-in-the-fight-over-trumps).

Posted at [3:24 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72786) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Figuring Out What Young Associates Want, Over 15 Coffees”: Katelyn Polantz of The National Law Journal has [an article](https://t.co/vhOprtdI2E) that begins, “Sean Marotta put on Twitter an open offer to have coffee, thinking that one or two young lawyers in Washington, D.C., might have interest in meeting him, a seventh-year associate in Hogan Lovells’ appellate practice.”

Posted at [3:20 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72785) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“U.S. Supreme Court Justices Samuel Alito and Sonia Sotomayor speaking today in South Carolina”: Andrew Brown and Jamie Lovegrove of The Post and Courier of Charleston, South Carolina have [this report](http://www.postandcourier.com/politics/u-s-supreme-court-justices-samuel-alito-and-sonia-sotomayor/article_4a64b746-9953-11e7-8f22-a738fe4c521c.html).

Posted at [2:14 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72784) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Waymo Trade Secrets Trial to Proceed After Uber Loses Appeal”: Susan Decker and Joel Rosenblatt of Bloomberg News have [this report](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-09-13/waymo-trade-secrets-trial-to-proceed-after-uber-loses-appeal) on two rulings ([here](http://www.cafc.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/opinions-orders/17-2130.Opinion.9-11-2017.1.PDF) and [here](http://www.cafc.uscourts.gov/sites/default/files/opinions-orders/17-2235.Opinion.9-11-2017.1.PDF)) that the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit](http://www.cafc.uscourts.gov) issued yesterday.

Posted at [2:10 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72783) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


Judge Sutton on the Confrontation Clause tension between [Craig](https://www.law.cornell.edu/supremecourt/text/497/836) and [Crawford](https://www.law.cornell.edu/supct/html/02-9410.ZS.html): [Sixth Circuit](http://www.ca6.uscourts.gov) Judge [Jeffrey S. Sutton](https://www.fjc.gov/history/judges/sutton-jeffrey-s.) issued [this important concurring opinion](http://www.opn.ca6.uscourts.gov/opinions.pdf/17a0216p-06.pdf#page=16) today.

Posted at [1:57 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72782) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


Washington State Supreme Court rules 6-3 that minor may be convicted for disseminating sexually explicit image of himself: You can access today’s ruling of the [Supreme Court of Washington State](https://www.courts.wa.gov/appellate_trial_courts/supremecourt/) at [this link](https://www.courts.wa.gov/opinions/pdf/936099.pdf).

Posted at [1:50 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72781) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Justice Souter’s Common Law”: Law professor [Charles L. Barzun](https://content.law.virginia.edu/faculty/profile/clb6x/1144315) has posted [this article](https://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=3035402) on SSRN (via “[Legal Theory Blog](http://lsolum.typepad.com/legaltheory/2017/09/barzun-on-souters-common-law.html)“).

Posted at [1:42 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72780) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Supreme Court Could Dismantle Popular Patent Challenge Next Term”: Tony Dutra of Bloomberg BNA has [this report](https://www.bna.com/supreme-court-dismantle-n57982087776/).

Posted at [1:37 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72779) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“The Racist Map Wins: The Supreme Court’s conservatives just ensured that Latino votes still won’t count in Texas.” Mark Joseph Stern has [this jurisprudence essay](http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/jurisprudence/2017/09/the_supreme_court_s_conservatives_just_ensured_that_latino_votes_still_won.html) online at Slate.

Posted at [1:34 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72778) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Bakers Can Be Artists, But They Still Can’t Discriminate; The Supreme Court should recognize that, however symbolic their products, Colorado businesses aren’t allowed to be anti-gay”: Law professor [Noah Feldman](http://hls.harvard.edu/faculty/directory/10257/Feldman) has [this essay](https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2017-09-13/bakers-can-be-artists-but-they-still-can-t-discriminate) online at Bloomberg View.

Posted at [1:32 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72777) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Edie Windsor Gave Me My Wife. And My Life.” Rhea Butcher has [this op-ed](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/13/opinion/edie-windsor-gay-rights.html) in today’s edition of The New York Times.

Posted at [1:26 PM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72776) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


Ramble on: Y. Peter Kang of Law360.com reports that “[Pa. Court Tosses ‘Excessively Rambling’ Med Mal Appeal](https://www.law360.com/articles/963128/pa-court-tosses-excessively-rambling-med-mal-appeal)” (subscription required for full access).

You can access Tuesday’s ruling of the [Superior Court of Pennsylvania](http://www.pacourts.us/courts/superior-court/) at [this link](http://www.pacourts.us/assets/opinions/Superior/out/Opinion%20-%20Affirmed%20-%2010324137623811662.pdf).

Regardless of how rambling the brief turned out to be — and it can be persuasively argued that any amount of rambling is too much where an appellate brief is concerned — the brief’s critical objective flaw, according to Tuesday’s ruling, was that it was 4,548 words longer than the applicable 14,000-word limit for principal briefs in Pennsylvania state court appeals.

Posted at [11:44 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72775) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“10 Things You Need To Know About Blue Slips: Republicans repeatedly used the tradition to block President Obama’s judicial nominees.” Christopher Kang has [this entry](http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/59b98494e4b02c642e4a1368) online at HuffPost.

Posted at [11:28 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72774) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


Wax eloquently: Law professor [Amy Wax](https://www.law.upenn.edu/cf/faculty/awax/) discussed on two occasions ([here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cb9Ey-SsNsg) and [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bLcHZXsCbY4)) with [Glenn Loury](https://www.brown.edu/Departments/Economics/Faculty/Glenn_Loury/louryhomepage/) at bloggingheads.tv [the controversial op-ed](http://www.philly.com/philly/opinion/commentary/paying-the-price-for-breakdown-of-the-countrys-bourgeois-culture-20170809.html) she recently co-authored.

You can access all of Wax’s blogginghead.tv appearances [via this link](https://bloggingheads.tv/?s=amy+wax).

Posted at [10:58 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72773) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“Court reveals another overseas-data fight between Google and feds”: Josh Gerstein of Politico.com has [this blog post](http://www.politico.com/blogs/under-the-radar/2017/09/14/google-overseas-data-court-battle-242708).

Posted at [10:48 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72772) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“When Junk Science About Sex Offenders Infects the Supreme Court”: David Feige has [this essay](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/12/opinion/when-junk-science-about-sex-offenders-infects-the-supreme-court.html) online at The New York Times.

Posted at [10:44 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72771) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“CEI Opposes PETA Monkey Business in Selfie Settlement”: The Competitive Enterprise Institute issued [this news release](https://cei.org/content/cei-opposes-peta-monkey-business-selfie-settlement) regarding [a proposed amicus brief](https://cei.org/sites/default/files/Naruto.53-2.proposed%20amicus.pdf) that the organization submitted yesterday to the [U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit](http://www.ca9.uscourts.gov).

On Tuesday, I had [this post](http://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/091217.html#072734) collecting coverage of the settlement.

Posted at [10:28 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72770) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)


“An Old Supreme Court Dream”: Linda Greenhouse has [this essay](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/14/opinion/supreme-court-immigration.html) online at The New York Times.

And in case you missed them, as I apparently did, in the second half of August, Greenhouse had essays titled “[What We’re in Danger of Losing](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/17/opinion/what-were-in-danger-of-losing.html)” and “[Eclipsing Dreams of Better Lives](https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/31/opinion/immigration-daca-supreme-court.html).”

Posted at [8:52 AM ](https://howappealing.abovethelaw.com/2017/09/14/#72769) by [Howard Bashman](mailto:appellateblog@hotmail.com)

# When Exactly Will These Biglaw Associates See Their Bonuses?
## Just because associates are getting market sized bonuses, it doesn't mean they're happy.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onFebruary 27, 2019 at 11:16 AMFebruary 27, 2019 at 11:07 AM
14
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/when-exactly-will-paul-hastings-associates-see-their-bonuses/&text=When%20Exactly%20Will%20These%20Biglaw%20Associates%20See%20Their%20Bonuses?)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/when-exactly-will-paul-hastings-associates-see-their-bonuses/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/02/when-exactly-will-paul-hastings-associates-see-their-bonuses/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
On the surface, there’s not too much remarkable about the bonus announcement made by Paul Hastings. The bonus scale is on par with the market, there’s extra money available for associates who had an especially good year, and associates who missed the hours requirement for [special summer bonuses ](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/the-raise-train-continues-reaching-11-u-s-offices-yesterday/)have an opportunity to true up if they hit the end-of-the-year billing targets.

Here’s the expected bonus schedule:



[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Read the full memo below.

So, if the basics are in line with the market standard, what’s there to complain about? Well, the announcement didn’t come out until February 25th and the compensation memo indicates that associates will be paid 2018 bonuses “in March” with no indication which of the 31 days of the month they might expect their money.

And some associates are pissed:

Paul Hastings just matched the market scale for bonuses, but is scheduling them to be paid “in March,” just showing a stunningly casual disregard for their associates’ ability to do any financial planning. Not only are we the last to pay out, but we still don’t even know by how much we’re last.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Yes, waiting until late February to make a move is Paul Hastings [standard operating procedure](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/associate-bonus-watch-better-late-than-never-2/), but that doesn’t mean all the associates are taking it with an accepting shrug. As a tipster reports:

Associates at PH are livid, and I think it invites an open question about whether or not a promise to “pay market” necessarily implies that you pay *near the same time* as the market (and not months later).

As Tom Petty crooned, waiting is the hardest part.

Please help us help you when it comes to bonus news at other firms. As soon as your firm’s bonus memo comes out, please [email it to us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Bonus) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Bonus”) or text us (646-820-8477). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts, please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish.

ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.

# Uh-Oh! Why Is This Biglaw Firm Deferring Partner Profits?
## This firm may not be out of the woods just yet...
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onAugust 16, 2016 at 12:59 PM
1
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/uh-oh-why-is-this-biglaw-firm-deferring-partner-profits/&text=Uh-Oh!%20Why%20Is%20This%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Deferring%20Partner%20Profits?)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/uh-oh-why-is-this-biglaw-firm-deferring-partner-profits/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/uh-oh-why-is-this-biglaw-firm-deferring-partner-profits/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
We looked at cash collections… the recapitalization process, the tax, and the cash flow of the firm… and we think the prudent thing to do is to defer the distribution.

It’s not unusual. We look at the cash needs of the EUME business on a month-by-month basis and defer partner profit distributions if needs be, this has happened a small number of times this year. But we want to be making those distributions every month by having the working capital position of the firm and our cash flow management where they need to be — that’s what we’re addressing right now.

— [Stuart Fuller](http://www.kwm.com/en/people/stuart-fuller), managing partner of 2,000-lawyer firm [King & Wood Mallesons](http://www.kwm.com/en), explaining why [profits were not being disbursed to partners](https://bol.bna.com/why-king-wood-mallesons-is-deferring-some-partner-profits/), despite the fact that partners were recently asked to [contribute $18.4 million to the firm](https://bol.bna.com/king-wood-mallesons-raises-18-4m-from-partners/) in a capital call. Fuller says that capital infusion won’t be paid until summer’s end, and the firm needed to pay U.K. partners’ taxes in July. Partners are still receiving their monthly draws.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
When asked if this would be the last month that partners’ profits would be deferred, Fuller said, “We are being very conservative with our working capital. We made that communication with our current partners… They have the entitlement to get that profit.”

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is an editor at Above the Law. Feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, or comments. [Litigation Finance](https://abovethelaw.com/litigation-finance-topic/), [Sponsored Content](https://abovethelaw.com/sponsored-content/)
# The 2020 Litigation Finance Survey Report
## Lawyers in every single industry we examined saw a significant uptick in firsthand experience with litigation finance.
By [Brian Dalton](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brian-dalton/)  
onJune 18, 2020 at 1:45 PMJune 18, 2020 at 1:36 PM
23
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-2020-litigation-finance-survey-report/&text=The%202020%20Litigation%20Finance%20Survey%20Report)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-2020-litigation-finance-survey-report/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2020/06/the-2020-litigation-finance-survey-report/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Since publishing our inaugural litigation finance survey in 2017, in partnership with [Lake Whillans](https://lakewhillans.com/), each subsequent iteration has been a story of ever-increasing traction for the practice of third-party funding. Our 2020 findings continue this narrative, and show a marked increase in the scale and momentum of the field’s development and acceptance. Perhaps the most striking finding in this year’s survey was a nearly 30 percent year-to-year increase in the percentage of respondents reporting that they had firsthand experience with litigation finance.

Other findings include:

- Lawyers in every single industry we examined saw a significant uptick (at least 10 percent) in firsthand experience with litigation finance.
- Nearly 100 percent (99.36 percent) of respondents with firsthand experience with litigation finance agreed that they would use litigation finance again.
- The proportion of respondents who would not consider litigation finance has plummeted since the 2019 survey.
- Roughly three-quarters of our respondents stated that litigation finance has become more relevant to their practice in the last year.
We note that our survey data was collected before the COVID-19 crisis and the financial turmoil it has caused. These findings demonstrate that litigation finance is well poised to meet the challenges companies and law firms are now facing. Claim monetization, financing of claimholders, and capital for law firms are core offerings of a litigation financier like Lake Whillans, and are likely to become even more attractive solutions to many more companies and firms as we move through 2020 and beyond. We expect that next year’s survey results will show marked differences as litigation finance further penetrates every segment of the market driven by new necessities and creative problem solving.

[Check out the full report on our survey findings here.](https://lakewhillans.com/research/2020-litigation-finance-survey-report/)

# It's Giuliani Time! Rudy Ritualistically Suicides One Case To Try To Save Trump From Another
## Thing is, I think Giuliani ineffectively inoculated Trump from campaign finance violations, while successfully murdering all credibility.
By [Elie Mystal](https://abovethelaw.com/author/elie-mystal/)  
onMay 2, 2018 at 11:52 PMMay 3, 2018 at 1:50 PM
508
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-giuliani-time-rudy-ritualistically-suicides-one-case-to-try-to-save-trump-from-another/&text=It’s%20Giuliani%20Time!%20Rudy%20Ritualistically%20Suicides%20One%20Case%20To%20Try%20To%20Save%20Trump%20From%20Another)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-giuliani-time-rudy-ritualistically-suicides-one-case-to-try-to-save-trump-from-another/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/its-giuliani-time-rudy-ritualistically-suicides-one-case-to-try-to-save-trump-from-another/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Rudy Giuliani (Photo by Rob Kim/Getty)

New Trump attorney Rudolph Giuliani went on Sean Hannity tonight and decided to completely blow up one of Donald Trump’s many legal cases. He blew it right the f**k up. It’s gone. Bye-bye.

Donald Trump has been arguing that he didn’t have a relationship with adult film actress Stormy Daniels, that he knew nothing about Michael Cohen’s hush-money payment to Daniels, and that he generally knew nothing about nobody. Trump went on Air Force One and said that he did not know about Michael Cohen’s payment.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
And Rudy Giuliani just went on cable television and basically [called Trump a liar](https://twitter.com/yashar/status/991855306350133249).

Yep, Giuliani said that Trump did reimburse Cohen, “funneling” the money through a law firm (which is not a word you want to use when your personal attorney is under investigation for fraud), but Trump “didn’t know the specifics of it.” A flabbergasted Sean Hannity actually pressed Giuliani on the point. He noted that Cohen has repeatedly said that he paid the money out of his own funds, without asking Trump. Giuliani said, “I don’t know. I have not investigated that. No reason to doubt him… I like Michael a lot.”

Yeah, so, Cohen didn’t even get a full-throated expression of support from Giuliani. Chew on that, Michael, when you are weighing whether or not to plead out and flip.

Trump supporters, I suppose, will argue that Trump just paid his lawyer $130,000 without asking why. And Cohen will still argue that he paid a porn star $130,000 without asking his client if he needed to. But… there is literally no rational person who could possibly believe all that any more. Trump people thought Mexico was going to pay for the wall, so I’m not impugning them with the heavy burden of rational thought, but Giuliani just told us what we already know: that Trump and Cohen have been lying about Stormy Daniels this whole time.

### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
So… you have to ask why. The answer is in the very next thing that came out of Giuliani’s mouth: “That money was not campaign money, sorry. I’m giving you a fact now that you don’t know. It’s not campaign money. No campaign finance violation.”

Donald Trump is personally concerned with the implication that he slept with a porn star. But his legal team has always, always, always been more concerned with the campaign finance violations. Paying hush money to a porn star is just gross. The campaign finance violation is a crime.

It seems likely that Giuliani made the decision to give up the ghost on the porn star payment, which was always a lie and a very obvious one at that, in an exchange to say the next line: the money was not “campaign” money, so… no violation. That’s the bigger fish, in Giuliani’s mind. Whether he actually consulted with anybody on the Trump legal team is a matter of debate. Who is actually running Trump’s legal team at this very physical moment is a matter of debate, [given the upheavals of today](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/05/ty-cobb-out-emmet-flood-in-constitutional-crisis-looms/).

The problem is that NOTHING Giuliani said actually inoculates Trump or Cohen from any possible campaign finance violation. Giuliani can say that “it’s not campaign money,” but that’s Rudy being worried about the entirely wrong thing. If Cohen made the payment, then that could be viewed as a campaign contribution. Paying somebody back for campaign contributions doesn’t… unmake the violation. Did Michael Cohen give Trump a personal loan? Was he paid back with interest? Just because Trump can donate as much of his own money to his campaign doesn’t mean Michael Cohen can.

Giuliani also said that Trump paid Cohen back over time, which could be a whole other ball of trouble for Trump. Was he, for instance, still paying Cohen off — sorry, “back,” — after it became clear that the F.B.I. was looking into Cohen? Was Trump… structuring the payments to avoid reporting requirements? Giuliani was not speaking with the discretion necessary of a defense lawyer who is going to risk going on television.

From Pilot and Above The Law  
And for good measure, Giuliani ALSO said that Trump fired James Comey because Comey would not publicly say that Trump was not a target of the F.B.I. investigation. … Which sounds MORE like obstruction of justice than ever before.

After Giuliani was hired, [I said on All In With Chris Hayes](http://www.msnbc.com/transcripts/all-in/2018-04-20) that the #Resistance shouldn’t at all be worried about Giuliani coming on the team… because Giuliani is an old, bad lawyer who was more likely than not to make things worse. I feel like it’s taken a week for me to be proven right. The man just went into a friendly interview, admitted that the president and his personal lawyer have been lying, ineffectively tried to set up a defense to campaign finance violations, and deepened the case for obstruction of justice.

And you know what? None of this probably really matters because Robert Mueller and the S.D.N.Y. probably already have all the documents they need to prove that Giuliani was, I guess, telling the truth about all the dirt he just exposed on TV.

Welcome to the Trump legal team, Emmet Flood. Hope you have had fun during your orientation.

Elie Mystal is the Executive Editor of Above the Law and the Legal Editor for [More Perfect](http://www.wnyc.org/shows/radiolabmoreperfect). He can be reached [@ElieNYC](https://twitter.com/ElieNYC?lang=en) on Twitter, or at [elie@abovethelaw.com](mailto:elie@abovethelaw.com). He will resist.

# Biglaw Associate Reportedly Loses Job Over Legal Tantrum Related To Kittens
## The associate in question allegedly had a hissy fit over some 'flea-ridden kittens.'
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMarch 5, 2024 at 12:12 PMMarch 6, 2024 at 1:09 PM
39
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-associate-reportedly-loses-job-over-legal-tantrum-related-to-kittens/&text=Biglaw%20Associate%20Reportedly%20Loses%20Job%20Over%20Legal%20Tantrum%20Related%20To%20Kittens)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-associate-reportedly-loses-job-over-legal-tantrum-related-to-kittens/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/03/biglaw-associate-reportedly-loses-job-over-legal-tantrum-related-to-kittens/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

‘Take care of this cat situation, right meow.’

An associate at a Biglaw firm in London has reportedly lost his job over something absolutely, pawsitively ridiculous.

As first reported by [RollOnFriday](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/exclusive-travers-smith-associate-dismissed-after-complaining-client-sold-him-flea), an associate at Travers Smith — a firm that brought in $244,327,250 gross revenue in 2022, putting it at No. 26 on most recent UK 100 ranking — was on a secondment at Inflexion, one of the firm’s private equity clients. While there, an employee posted on the company’s internal messaging app, attempting to sell some kittens. The associate jumped at the chance, offering to take two, but little did they know that this attempt to buy some pets would end in catastrophe.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
One week later, the associate attempted to return the kittens because they had fleas. That’s when all of the trouble started. From RollOnFriday:

[The seller] refused, but over the next couple of weeks the Travers associate repeatedly messaged her to say that she needed to take the kittens back and refund him because their fleas meant they were not sold as described, sources told ROF.

His requests culminated in an eight page letter which set out “all his legal and statutory rights” and demanded that the seller take the cats back and refund him or he would initiate court proceedings against her, said sources.

What a sourpuss. From there, a chain of events began that would land the associate’s career in the litter box.

Inflexion reported the associate to HR, HR went to legal, legal went to Travers, and the associate’s secondment was lost. Travers Smith reportedly asked the associate to apologize to the seller at Inflexion and donate the cats to shelter. According to ROF, the associate allegedly refused to give the cats away for free, and said they would do so if, and only if, the firm refunded the purchase price.

# Solicitor General Don Verrilli's Surprising Credit Card Debt
## Why does a wealthy former Biglaw partner carry credit card debt at high interest rates?
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)  
onJune 3, 2016 at 6:28 PMJune 6, 2016 at 11:21 AM
31
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/solicitor-general-don-verrillis-surprising-credit-card-debt/&text=Solicitor%20General%20Don%20Verrilli’s%20Surprising%20Credit%20Card%20Debt)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/solicitor-general-don-verrillis-surprising-credit-card-debt/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/solicitor-general-don-verrillis-surprising-credit-card-debt/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Your Honors, can you spare a dime? (Photo of Donald B. Verrilli Jr. by Mark Wilson/Getty Images)

Deities of the legal profession: they’re just like us! They carry too much credit card debt, at excessive interest rates.

Back in 2009, we arched an eyebrow at Supreme Court nominee Sonia Sotomayor’s [$30,000 in dentist and credit card bills](https://abovethelaw.com/2009/06/does-judge-sotomayor-need-a-visit-from-suze-orman/). Conventional wisdom in personal finance frowns upon carrying such big balances, especially given the usually high rates that accompany credit card debt (as opposed to, say, secured debt like a home mortgage).

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
But it seems that Justice Sotomayor isn’t the only high-flying legal eagle to ignore this advice. A tipster recently drew our attention to the financial disclosure forms of the [outgoing Solicitor General](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/solicitor-general-don-verrilli-to-step-down-perhaps-before-all-scotus-opinions-are-announced/), Donald Verrilli Jr. If you look at his [2012 form](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Donald-B-Verrilli-2012Form278certified.pdf) (page 13) and his [2015 form](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/06/Donald-B-Verilli-2015Form278.pdf) (page 6), you’ll see five-figure credit card balances at rates ranging from 12 to 23 percent. We share our source’s puzzlement:

How does a former longtime law firm partner consistently carry credit card debt with double-digit interest rates? What sort of basic personal finance lessons did he miss along the way?

Either he’s weirdly broke/illiquid (doesn’t seem to be the case!) or he’s casually indifferent to basic economic sense, which kind of suggests we need higher taxes (which we do)!

My money is on casual indifference. The amounts in question, while in the five figures, are probably too small for Verrilli to care about. On his home mortgage, a much more significant sum (between $500,001 and $1 million), he has a very nice rate of 3.125 percent.

So I wouldn’t be surprised if this consumer debt is just an oversight. If you look at the other pages of his disclosures, you’ll see ample liquid assets that could easily be used to eliminate those pesky credit card balances. Don Verrilli is not a poor man. Back in 2011, when the former Jenner & Block partner was confirmed as SG, his net worth clocked in at [more than $4 million](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/06/musical-chairs-don-verrilli-confirmed-as-solicitor-general/).

The members of the Supreme Court like to [“CVSG”](http://www.scotusblog.com/reference/educational-resources/glossary-of-legal-terms/) — “Call for the View of the Solicitor General” — but they might want to ignore him when it comes to personal finance.

(P.S. One possibility that just occurred to me: could Verrilli be taking advantage of some kind of 0% APR balance transfer offer? If you avail yourself of such an offer and then have to list it in a federal financial disclosure, do you list the interest rate as the 0% introductory rate, or the rate that kicks in after the introductory period ends? If you know the answer to this question, please feel free to [email me](mailto:dlat@abovethelaw.com?subject=Don%20Verrilli).)

UPDATE (6/6/2016, 11:10 a.m.): We’ve received some interesting reader mail in response to this story; thanks, readers! Several of the messages raise the possibility that Verrilli isn’t carrying a balance; pays his credit card bills in full each month, perhaps to get points or miles (which is a best practice of personal finance); and just happened to have a high-spending month at the end of the reporting period (maybe because of spending on holiday gifts right before the end of the reporting period on December 31).

This is certainly possible. It’s worth noting, however, that if you read a lot of federal financial disclosures (as we do here at ATL), you rarely see any credit card debt under “Liabilities” — which is why Verrilli’s jumped out at us. For example, take this [2014 report on the Supreme Court justices’ disclosures](https://abovethelaw.com/2014/06/underneath-their-robes-a-detailed-dive-into-the-justices-financial-disclosures/) — the only justice who reported credit card debt was Sotomayor, even though the justices all presumably have credit cards that at any given time of the month have some balance on them.

Here’s the [relevant guidance](https://www.oge.gov/Web/278eGuide.nsf/Chapters/Liabilities?opendocument) from the Office of Government Ethics on reporting credit card debt, which notes that the following type of debt does not have to be disclosed:

From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Revolving charge accounts, such as credit card balances, if the outstanding liability did not exceed $10,000 at the close of the reporting period.

This explains why it’s rare to see credit card on federal financial disclosures. Many officials either (1) pay off all their credit card debt, or at least get it down to below $10,000, right before the end of the relevant reporting period, or (2) don’t have balances exceeding $10,000 in any event (whether they carry these balances or not).

In Don Verrilli’s case, he didn’t bother to get his debt below $10,000 prior to filing his disclosures (or perhaps he or his assistant misread the admittedly complex forms and instructions). So that’s why his credit card debt jumped out at us (and our initial tipster); it’s so unusual to see credit card debt listed on these forms for officials in his type of position.

# This Biglaw Practice Area Is Not, What You'd Call, Flourishing
## We'll let you speculate why this legal specialty is in a slump.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onOctober 7, 2020 at 5:17 PMOctober 8, 2020 at 11:30 PM
1

Hint: The practice area has seen headcount fall by 21 percent this year.

# Taylor Swift Infiltrates Biglaw Recruiting
## What a way to make a splash.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJuly 27, 2023 at 3:44 PMJuly 27, 2023 at 2:32 PM
7
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/taylor-swift-infiltrates-biglaw-recruiting/&text=Taylor%20Swift%20Infiltrates%20Biglaw%20Recruiting)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/taylor-swift-infiltrates-biglaw-recruiting/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/07/taylor-swift-infiltrates-biglaw-recruiting/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Photo by Octavio Jones/TAS23/Getty Images for for TAS Rights Management)

Legal recruiting is all about getting the right attorneys into the right jobs. But to do that, recruiters have to get the attention of busy Biglaw lawyers and convince them to hitch their lateral career plans to the recruiter’s wagon. Especially when in-demand attorneys get a constant stream of recruiter correspondence, well, that’s no easy feat.

One recruiter is using the Summer of Swift to get Biglaw associates to respond. Above the Law tipsters have shared a recruiter email larded up with Taylor references, lyrics, and song titles. What an excellent way to stand out from the pack.

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Check out the email for yourself.

From: Buddy Apple
Sent: Wednesday, July 26, 2023 10:09 AM
To:
Subject: Lateral Haze? SWIFTly enter your new Era

[Name], are you Ready For It? Let us help you through the Lateral Haze and into your next Era.

It’s me. Hi. You’re not the problem, it’s the market. But really. If this unpredictable lateral market has you discouraged, you’re not alone. While it is anything but normal, we are seeing new searches posted daily and firms are still hiring!

If you or someone you know is interested in a lateral move, let our expertise and connections bring good karma your way.

No Bad Blood here, just the recruiting team of your Wildest Dreams:

IT’S A LOVE STORY, JUST SAY YES:

Just like Taylor Swift’s music, we’ve aged well, and ourtrio of recruiters have a combined 25+ years of experience. We are former Big Law and government attorneys, and last year was our most successful year ever.

SHAKE IT OFF TO YOUR NEXT JOB:

We will assist you to become the best Bejeweled version of yourself! When you walk into that interview, you will shimmer. We help you every step of the way, from resume edits/suggestions to interview preparation, interview scheduling, and salary negotiation.

THEY’VE GOT A BLANK SPACE (ON THIS APPLICATION), AND WE’LL WRITE YOUR NAME:

Let us do the hard work. First, we connect via a brief phone call to hear more about you and your ideal position. Next, we send you job postings from the markets of your choosing. Lastly, you pick where you want to be submitted, and voila. We handle the rest from there and make you stand out as the most competitive applicant.

ANYTHING BUT A CRUEL SUMMER:

While this market is anything but normal, opportunities exist if you know where to look! We often receive unpublished job orders and are in regular communication with our clients. We currently have multiple candidates interviewing + receiving competitive offers.

LOOK WHAT YOU MADE ME DO:

We won’t make you do anything you don’t want, but we would love to briefly chat if you or someone you know is interested. We won’t share your resume or information unless you explicitly give us permission. Confidentiality is our #1 priority.

Now is the IDEAL time to connect with us for moves later this summer and into the fall. We maintain an active national practice assisting attorneys in markets including Atlanta, Boston, California, Chicago, DC, Denver, the Midwest, Nashville, NYC, the Pacific Northwest, and Texas, among others.

We look forward to connecting with you soon.

Buddy

Buddy Apple, Esq.

Managing Director

Wegman Partners, LLC

We stan a [good T. Swift reference](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/06/jury-duty-taylor-swift-arrest/) here at Above the Law, so kudos to this recruiter. You definitely got our attention.

# Attorney Sentenced To 7 1/2 Years In Prison For 'Systematically Defrauding' Biglaw Firm
## The judge was unimpressed with his excuse.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 23, 2021 at 10:42 AMSeptember 24, 2021 at 12:22 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/attorney-sentenced-to-7-1-2-years-in-prison-for-systematically-defrauding-biglaw-firm/&text=Attorney%20Sentenced%20To%207%201/2%20Years%20In%20Prison%20For%20‘Systematically%20Defrauding’%20Biglaw%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/attorney-sentenced-to-7-1-2-years-in-prison-for-systematically-defrauding-biglaw-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/09/attorney-sentenced-to-7-1-2-years-in-prison-for-systematically-defrauding-biglaw-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A former Cooley attorney, James Brien, was [sentenced to seven and a half years in prison](https://www.law360.com/articles/1420556) for “systematically defrauding” the law firm and another former employer, the English governmental agency Commonwealth Secretariat, for over £640,000 ($886,000). His scheme involved diverting payments made by both the Commonwealth Secretariat and Cooley to his own bank account.

At the Commonwealth Secretariat, Brien switched payment details for money owed to a consultant, Phil Simmons, to his own bank account. He followed that up with more fictitious invoices, to receive a total of £146,000 from that employer. He left the agency in 2018 over an unrelated disciplinary issue.

As [reported by](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/ex-cooley-lawyer-jailed-audacious-ps600000-fraud) Roll on Friday, that was far from the end of the story. He also was convicted of diverting funds to his own bank account while employed as special counsel at Cooley:

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
But the 48-year-old was also an expert fibber, and he managed to secure a job at Cooley by lying about the reasons for his departure.

Once he was in the door, the lawyer embarked on a new scam which saw him divert £403,000 paid by two clients to Cooley into his own account, followed by £90,000 from the Maldives government. His fraud only came to light when Simmons popped up and asked about a payment he was owed.

Brien was convicted of three counts of fraud and Judge Martin Griffiths called him “a strange person as far as I can see,” and “gave evidence with a capacity to lie, repeatedly.” And the judge referred to Brien’s blaming of an unknown hacker for the financial malfeasance as “complete moonshine.”

I guess the judge was happy to tell Brien how he really feels.

# A Biglaw Firm That Really Cares
## A look at Jenner & Block's co-managing partners.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onMay 21, 2021 at 10:43 AMMay 27, 2021 at 2:51 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/a-biglaw-firm-that-really-cares/&text=A%20Biglaw%20Firm%20That%20Really%20Cares)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/a-biglaw-firm-that-really-cares/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/05/a-biglaw-firm-that-really-cares/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Listen, I am surprised as anyone. When I sat down to interview Jenner & Block’s Co-Managing Partners Katya Jestin and Randy Mehrberg, I hardly anticipated being wowed by the firm’s dedication to social justice and pro bono representations, but here we are.

In this episode of The Jabot, I chat with Katya and Randy about their overall philosophy for managing a Biglaw firm, prioritizing diversity, the challenges in trying to create a unified culture across a giant firm and how has the pandemic heightened those issues. We also talk about Jenner & Block’s representation of Stacey Abrams’s Fair Fight Action and the need to modernize the Voting Rights Act.

The Jabot podcast is an offshoot of the Above the Law brand focused on the challenges women, people of color, LGBTQIA, and other diverse populations face in the legal industry. Our name comes from none other than the Notorious Ruth Bader Ginsburg and the jabot (decorative collar) she wore when delivering dissents from the bench. It’s a reminder that even when we aren’t winning, we’re still a powerful force to be reckoned with.

Happy listening!


Kathryn Rubino is a Senior Editor at Above the Law, and host of [The Jabot podcast.](https://open.spotify.com/show/1XC11QhFCWxWr4NQrk2sEA) AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Why The Mid-Market May Be The Prime Market For Tech Development
## Striking a balance between informed user feedback and a true partnership outlook make these firms great candidates.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 16, 2021 at 11:45 AM
0
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/why-the-mid-market-may-be-the-prime-market-for-tech-development/&text=Why%20The%20Mid-Market%20May%20Be%20The%20Prime%20Market%20For%20Tech%20Development)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/why-the-mid-market-may-be-the-prime-market-for-tech-development/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/02/why-the-mid-market-may-be-the-prime-market-for-tech-development/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There’s always a splash when an elite firm announces a partnership with a new legal technology firm. But as we discussed on [Legaltech Week](https://www.lawsitesblog.com/2021/02/legaltech-week-2021-02-05-legalweek-post-mortem-plus-the-panelists-top-stories.html) last episode, there are pitfalls with firm partnerships. Big firms can see the product as their proprietary tool and impede development by driving innovation toward their own parochial needs. With all the fanfare, a company just might set themselves up with a pair of golden handcuffs.

But products aren’t getting anywhere without user feedback. Perhaps the answer is the oft-overlooked mid-market.

This idea really hit me while catching up with Will Norton of [SimplyAgree](https://simplyagree.com/) during the Legalweek virtual festivities. SimplyAgree rolled out version 2.0 of its deal management tool in October and it already appears to be taking off like gangbusters, with December seeing the company’s biggest month of activity with about double the engagement. As one might expect, all the credit goes to the feedback the company gathered from its earlier release and constant engagement with users to find out what people want and to probe them with questions like, “But if we built this again from scratch, how should it look?”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
Every time I talk to Norton, he makes a great counter-intuitive point. Over the summer, he told me that, even though it seems more labor-intensive, the company had [stepped up individualized trainings](https://abovethelaw.com/2020/08/iltaon-announcements-run-gamut-from-tool-for-combatting-racial-injustice-to-long-expected-acquisition/) rather than stick with the usual group setting during the pandemic because they were getting better engagement and adoption from more one-on-one remote trainings. Which makes a lot of sense but was certainly not what I expected to hear in a world where technology is applauding its mass collaboration tools. So I was ready for the unexpected take in a world where tech companies are always trumpeting their sexy initial investments from Biglaw heavies.

“If I were advising another startup I’d say start with Am Law 200 firms who will keep working with you on the product to get it better,” Norton said. “You can have closer connections and relationships with chief technical officers and partnership.” It makes a lot of sense. For a big firm to take a chance on a new product it’s naturally going to take some measure of control that tech companies may not be ready to cede. Small firms offer a lot of feedback, but if the users aren’t technically savvy themselves it may not translate into something that can drive the product forward. But mid-market firms may be a Goldilocks zone of tech development with dedicated IT professionals on staff to partner with, but not big enough to think they automatically own the process.

For Simply Agree, the expansion into the big firm world is underway, but relationships with mid-market firms remain invaluable as the transactional side undergoes a philosophical transformation with attorneys moving away from delegation and embracing more direct control of the whole process through tech.

There’s not a single path to innovation in any space, let alone the legal market. Maximizing revenue streams with big ticket commitments may work for some and it may burn others. Padding the coffers with venture capital money may ease the path to success for some while leaving others beholden to short-sighted masters. Monitoring a company’s path can shine a light for another aspiring product, but it can also help clients figure out exactly what kind of product they’re buying.
