# The Biglaw Recruitment Process Is Worse For Everyone
## The hellscape that is pre-recruitment is incredibly popular.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 22, 2024 at 4:46 PMApril 22, 2024 at 4:33 PM
6
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-biglaw-recruitment-process-is-worse-for-everyone/&text=The%20Biglaw%20Recruitment%20Process%20Is%20Worse%20For%20Everyone)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-biglaw-recruitment-process-is-worse-for-everyone/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-biglaw-recruitment-process-is-worse-for-everyone/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

(Image via Getty)

When you tell people outside of the legal profession that you (functionally) interview for the Biglaw job you’re going to take after law school graduation after only completing 1/3 of law school, they think it’s wild. Like how do firms know how good you’ll be as a lawyer if you haven’t even completed the majority of your legal training? How do you know what job you want two years in the future? Sure, we’ve all been indoctrinated into the system such that it no longer seems weird, but it is a bizarre system.

And yet, it’s getting even worse.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
The on-campus interview process — which placed initial interviews for summer associateships that beget post-graduation employment offers in the weeks before 2L year or the early part of the semester — is no longer the hotness for Biglaw firms. In an effort to have first dibs on the best and brightest, law schools are taking direct applications from 1Ls as early as April. And, as[ reported by](https://news.bloomberglaw.com/business-and-practice/big-law-skips-ahead-of-on-campus-recruiting-in-race-for-talent) Bloomberg Law, the direct application process is very popular at some Biglaw firms:

“This direct hire process will likely be filling about 50% of our class, at least,” said Nicole Wanzer, director of attorney recruiting at Morrison Foerster. “Were we to wait for traditional OCI and lean only on traditional OCI, we feel like we would be missing out on some of the talent that’s getting picked up earlier in the process.”

The shift has had a snowball effect. Weil Gotshal & Manges has already [opened](https://careers.weil.com/) applications for its 2025 summer program, allowing first-year law students to apply directly—a process dubbed “pre-OCI”. Other prominent players such as Jones Day, Milbank LLP, Paul Hastings, and Davis Polk & Wardwell open up their direct applications as early as mid-April for jobs that start the summer after the second year of school is completed. MoFo is launching its own advanced consideration application system for first-year students this year, which opens May 1.

And in response, law schools are [moving up their OCI ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/02/fomo-in-biglaw-recruiting-will-more-law-schools-switch-their-dates-for-on-campus-recruiting/)to the beginning of the summer.

So what happened to derail the import — and established timeframe — of OCI? Back in 2018, the National Association for Law Placement [ditched their rules](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/the-recruiting-game-done-changed/) which dictated how and when firms could contact candidates. We called it “[organized chaos](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/12/new-nalp-rules-for-law-school-recruitment-seem-to-promote-organized-chaos/)” when announced. With the benefit of hindsight, NALP’s executive director Nikia Gray calls it “the free market system.” But in reality, it seems like a lot closer to a shitshow.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Students in particular are losing out in the new system. Putting the stress of the summer associate interview process before they’ve completed their first full year just sucks. Especially when you consider some of the other developments that came once NALP noped out — like [exploding offers](https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/biglaws-exploding-offers-are-adding-unnecessary-stress-to-law-students-lives/) that slash the amount of time law students can evaluate a firm or interview with their competitors.

And firms are increasingly concerned that they have less information with which to judge potential associates.

Morrison Foerster is considering adding new assessments or writing exercises to its interview process to help gauge applicants, Wanzer said.

“With the speed of the process, it’s definitely exacerbated the challenge to make sure that the talent you’re seeing—and, more so, the offers that you’re extending—are to people who are going to succeed,” she said.

Maybe we just should have kept the old system before Biglaw devolved into a prisoner’s dilemma. But what do I know.

# What It's Really Like To Be The Managing Partner At A Law Firm
## Carrying the entire weight of a law firm on your shoulders is hard work.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 30, 2019 at 1:15 PMAugust 30, 2019 at 11:05 AM
39
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/what-its-really-like-to-be-the-managing-partner-at-a-law-firm/&text=What%20It’s%20Really%20Like%20To%20Be%20The%20Managing%20Partner%20At%20A%20Law%20Firm)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/what-its-really-like-to-be-the-managing-partner-at-a-law-firm/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/08/what-its-really-like-to-be-the-managing-partner-at-a-law-firm/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))


The weight of the world sits on you, so the people in the firm — attorneys and staff alike — depend on you to thrive. That was really weighty.

— Richard Scheff, currently a partner at Armstrong Teasdale, [explains to Law.com](https://www.law.com/2019/08/27/when-a-managing-partner-exits-a-firm-does-it-signal-new-career-goals-or-firm-troubles/) on why he left Montgomery McCracken, his firm of 28 years. At the time of his departure from Montgomery McCracken he was both the firm’s executive chairman and the firm’s largest revenue generator.

# Biglaw Firm Showers Associates With Cold, Hard Cash
## Exciting news!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onApril 15, 2021 at 11:44 AMApril 15, 2021 at 11:25 AM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/katten-special-bonus-2021/&text=Biglaw%20Firm%20Showers%20Associates%20With%20Cold,%20Hard%20Cash)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/katten-special-bonus-2021/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/katten-special-bonus-2021/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Another day, another Biglaw firm that’s offering tremendous heaps of money to its associates and counsel for all of their hard work during the pandemic. By [our count](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/03/special-bonus-tracker-2021/), dozens upon dozens of law firms (64, to be exact) have offered special bonuses thus far, leaving us to wonder which firms are waiting it out until the bitter end of the cycle to thank their lawyers for all they’ve done in these unprecedented times.

The latest firm to announce bonuses is Katten Muchin, a firm that brought in $669,709,000 gross revenue in 2019, placing it at #63 in the most recent Am Law 100 ranking. The firm has of course matched the Davis Polk special bonus scale, and its bonus matrix can be seen below (full memo on the [next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/katten-special-bonus-2021/2/)):



[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Although the firm’s standard billable requirement for bonuses is 2000 hours, Katten is only requiring 1900 hours annualized (including pro bono, firm citizenship, and firm legal work) for these special bonuses. The May payment is based on four months of work, and the September payment is based on eight months of work. The firm is offering two catch-up payment periods in August and December so that everyone will have the opportunity to reap these rewards.

Congratulations to everyone at the firm on these fantastic bonuses!

(Flip to the [next page](https://abovethelaw.com/2021/04/katten-special-bonus-2021/2/) to see the full memo from Katten.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Elite Biglaw Firms Suck At Client Service
## Clients have spoken -- the top Biglaw firms ain't all that.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 14, 2018 at 11:15 AMJune 14, 2018 at 1:58 PM
30
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/elite-biglaw-firms-suck-at-client-service/&text=Elite%20Biglaw%20Firms%20Suck%20At%20Client%20Service)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/elite-biglaw-firms-suck-at-client-service/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/elite-biglaw-firms-suck-at-client-service/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
When you think of the very top of the Am Law 200 — say the top 20 Biglaw firms or so, you probably assume those are the very best of the best, and that clients who engage those firms receive legal services second to none. But what if the reality was far different?

That’s one of the [fascinating findings from the GC Thought Leaders Experiment,](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/06/12/large-pedigreed-firms-underperform-on-service-quality-compared-to-other-firms/) they asked in-house departments to evaluate 1,400 legal matters and the results show that hiring the biggest of the Biglaw firms did not result in better service. Indeed, the Am Law 21-200 did better than the top 20 across several metrics including responsiveness, efficiency, quality of work, and solutions focus. Hell, they did better on every metric they tested for. And what’s more, the differences are amplified when you compare the Am Law top 20 to the Am Law 101-200.

The survey methodology didn’t ask respondents to rank firms, but instead asked them to rate the service on specific matters. Even when controlling for variables such as the size of the matter, the length of the firm/company relationship and the type of legal work, the surprising results were the same:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
Note that this isn’t an opinion survey: no one ranked firms. These are 28 companies’ evaluations of over 1,400 legal matters; and because we knew which firms and lawyers handled each matter, we were able to determine which firms performed better or worse, as well as identify trends. We also controlled for many variables (such as type of legal work, length of client/firm relationship, size of legal matter, amount of spend with the firm, and the like) to test and re-test our findings. But the result was the same. On the whole, when clients look to hire firms, bigger or more pedigreed is not necessarily better.

It probably makes sense that some factors, such as cost/efficiency, aren’t the elite firms’ strong suit — after all, clients pay a premium for the best of the best attorneys. But the Am Law top 20 are even losing when it comes to solutions focus — defined as “is the outside lawyer demonstrating creativity, strategic thinking, and a ‘yes, and here’s how’ (rather than ‘no’) mindset?” — which is the most relevant factor when clients evaluate whether they’d recommend the firm. The Am Law 20 scores 4.34 in that metric, compared with 4.53 for the Am Law 21-200 and 4.56 for the Am Law 101-200.

So why are the top Biglaw firms falling behind on this essential skill set?

This, too, may be a by-product of staffing leverage (associate to partner ratio) at the largest and most pedigreed firms: as bigger teams liaise with the client, the lead partner may not learn quite as much about the business or matter. And this may be exacerbated by the reality that in-house lawyers are stretched too thin with less time to work with outside lawyers; more than before in-house teams are expected to focus their time and energy collaborating with internal clients to drive business results.

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)

From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)
### [ Generative AI In Legal Work — What’s Fact And What’s Fiction? ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit) 
Zach Warren from the Thomson Reuters Institute discusses the potential and the pitfalls.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)  
But if clients are consistently less happy with the elite firms, why exactly do they remain at the top of the heap? The authors, Firoz Dattu and Aaron Kotok, point to several reasons that elite Biglaw firms continue to bring in work, such as the possibility that they have reached a tipping point or the high cost associated with switching firms that have an established relationship between the firm and the company, but most importantly that there’s a lack of information to in-house decision makers:

It’s that the legal market has an information problem: we don’t know which firms are performing better, so we are forced to default to brand (and high cost) as proxies for quality. But that is changing, as discussed in this[ Above the Law article](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/if-a-tree-falls-in-biglaw-and-no-one-hears-it-does-it-make-a-sound-meet-firoz-dattu/). Clients, in essence, are finding out that the blue chip firms of the past are not necessarily the blue chip firms of the present (and future). Likewise, the “insurance” rationale for choosing certain firms for high-stakes work based on historical reputation should dissipate over time (but won’t disappear).

Now that the information is out there, it’s up to the biggest Biglaw firms to respond.

Kathryn Rubino is an editor at Above the Law. AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter ([@Kathryn1](https://twitter.com/Kathryn1)).

# Non-Sequiturs: 03.11.18
## * This great profile of Chuck Cooper, by Tierney Sneed of TPM, includes more details on why he [withdrew from the solicitor general sweepstakes](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/02/breaking-chuck-cooper-withdraws-from-the-solicitor-general-sweepstakes/). [[Talking Points Memo](https://talkingpointsmemo.com/muckraker/chuck-cooper-jeff-sessions-trump-mueller)] * A team from Quinn Emanuel, led by [high-profile hire Alex Spiro](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/10/quinn-emanuel-pulls-off-coup-with-big-time-criminal-defense-hire/), is repping Jay-Z in a trademark fight. Can Biglaw + Beyonce be far behind? [[Hollywood Reporter](https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/thr-esq/jay-zs-roc-nation-asks-court-dismiss-iconix-brand-groups-licensing-lawsuit-1092556)] * Steven Brill, the godfather of modern legal journalism, launches his latest venture: [NewsGuard](https://newsguardtechnologies.com/), which "uses journalism to fight fake news." [[Dewey B Strategic](https://www.deweybstrategic.com/2018/03/legal-news-pioneer-steven-brill-takes-on-fake-news-with-newsguard-how-will-news-aggregation-platforms-respond.html)] * Speaking of "fake news," leading media lawyer Charles Glasser puts President Trump's "war on the press" in a broader, global context. [[Daily Caller](http://dailycaller.com/2018/03/08/trading-blood-for-ink-the-real-war-on-the-press-is-happening-all-over-the-world/)] * Still on the subject of POTUS v. Press, is the media being played in the Stormy Daniels drama? Joel Cohen and Dale Degenshein think so. [[Law & Crime](https://lawandcrime.com/opinion/the-press-is-being-played-stormy-daniels-lawsuit-against-trump-is-a-money-grab/)] * Strange bedfellows at One First Street: Adam Feldman looks at Supreme Court cases featuring unusual ideological alliances. [[Empirical SCOTUS](https://empiricalscotus.com/2018/03/07/when-opposites-attract/)] * Protip for litigators and litigants: don't tick off Judge Frederic Block (or any other judge presiding over your case, for that matter). [[artnet](https://news.artnet.com/art-world/5pointz-graffiti-art-vara-lawsuit-1234652)] * If our [five Biglaw business development tips](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/03/biglaw-business-development-5-insights-from-chief-marketing-officers/?rf=1) weren't enough for you, Jane Genova adds two more for your consideration. [[Law And More](http://lawandmore.typepad.com/law_and_more/2018/03/biglaw-marketing-has-become-zero-sum-game.html)] * How can technology be harnessed to bridge the justice gap? [Neota Logic](https://www.neotalogic.com/) has some ideas. [[Artificial Lawyer](https://www.artificiallawyer.com/2018/03/08/neota-logic-helps-deliver-access-justice-legal-tech/)]
By [David Lat](https://abovethelaw.com/author/david-lat/)

[Biglaw](https://abovethelaw.com/biglaw/), [In-House Counsel](https://abovethelaw.com/in-house-counsel/)
# 'Tone-Deaf And Unseemly': In-House Counsel A Bit Put Off By Biglaw Salary Hikes
## Don't try to pass the extra expense off on your clients, Biglaw.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 11, 2021 at 4:30 PMJune 11, 2021 at 4:06 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/tone-deaf-and-unseemly-in-house-counsel-a-bit-put-off-by-biglaw-salary-hikes/&text=‘Tone-Deaf%20And%20Unseemly’:%20In-House%20Counsel%20A%20Bit%20Put%20Off%20By%20Biglaw%20Salary%20Hikes)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/tone-deaf-and-unseemly-in-house-counsel-a-bit-put-off-by-biglaw-salary-hikes/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2021/06/tone-deaf-and-unseemly-in-house-counsel-a-bit-put-off-by-biglaw-salary-hikes/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This isn’t of too much consequence or import to us if firms don’t attempt to pass the cost through to clients in the form of higher rates. But even if they say they don’t/won’t, clients may tend to wonder.

It seems a bit tone-deaf and unseemly in this market and coming off of the pandemic (with so much economic dislocation) for firms to be raising salaries to these levels and talking publicly about bonuses and how well partners are doing. Discretion would be the much better part of valor here.

— the general counsel of a financial services company, [commenting](https://www.law.com/corpcounsel/2021/06/10/seems-a-bit-tone-deaf-clients-react-to-big-law-associate-pay-bump/) anonymously on the recent wave of salary increases that are rocking the Biglaw market in the wake of associate bonus payouts that could reach as high as $164K, depending on class year.

# More Raises Ahead For The Legal Profession In 2017
## This is certainly good news for the industry overall.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onAugust 31, 2016 at 4:54 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/more-raises-ahead-for-the-legal-profession-in-2017/&text=More%20Raises%20Ahead%20For%20The%20Legal%20Profession%20In%202017)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/more-raises-ahead-for-the-legal-profession-in-2017/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/08/more-raises-ahead-for-the-legal-profession-in-2017/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
High off of this summer’s [MoneyLaw](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/moneylaw/) raises, you might not think things could get better for the legal profession — at least not in terms of compensation. But there may be more good news in 2017.

According to [Time](http://time.com/money/4470679/best-jobs-salary-increases-2017/), staffing company Robert Half has identified 10 jobs poised for salary bumps in 2017, and of that list, six are in or related to the legal industry:

- Litigation support / e-Discovery professionals: 7.3% (junior level) to 8.9% (senior level)
- Lawyers: 5.8% (senior level) to 6.9% (midlevel)
- Compliance professionals: 6.4% (senior level) to 6.9% (midlevel)
- First-year legal associates (large law firm): 6.2%
- Contract managers: 5.4%
- Compliance analysts: 5.4%
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
My guess is the the “First-year legal associates (large law firm)” entry will just be the market ripple effect as firms catch up to the Cravath scale, or make other, smaller adjustments to their compensation based on that bump. But it is encouraging for others outside of Biglaw associate ranks, like ediscovery and compliance professionals, to see their sliver of the market is improving as well.

The Time article pays particular attention to the salary increase expected in compliance:

Most legal workers, for instance, can expect a salary bump in line with the national average, according to the firm’s data. But for compliance managers — a role that [senior executive director Paul] McDonald says has grown steadily since the [introduction of Dodd-Frank](http://time.com/money/3949583/dodd-frank-financial-reform-anniversary/) and other financial reforms — salaries will climb 6.9%.

This is certainly good news for the industry overall.

# This Is Absolutely What You Need To Start Calling The Lawyer In Your Life
## You won’t be able to unhear it.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 15, 2023 at 11:43 AMSeptember 15, 2023 at 11:25 AM
25
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/this-is-absolutely-what-you-need-to-start-calling-the-lawyer-in-your-life/&text=This%20Is%20Absolutely%20What%20You%20Need%20To%20Start%20Calling%20The%20Lawyer%20In%20Your%20Life)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/this-is-absolutely-what-you-need-to-start-calling-the-lawyer-in-your-life/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/09/this-is-absolutely-what-you-need-to-start-calling-the-lawyer-in-your-life/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
There are actually a lot of things you can call a lawyer: attorney, counselor, esquire… plus the job specific titles like prosecutor, solicitor, barrister. The list is long (but don’t call them doctor, [that’s just dumb](https://abovethelaw.com/2011/11/any-lawyer-who-calls-himself-doctor-like-a-ph-d-should-get-punched-in-the-mouth/).)

You may think with all these rhetorical options, no more are needed. There was a time, not so long ago, when I would have agreed. But then I heard the term “attack librarian.” Combining the penchant for research with an argumentative streak is a brilliant move. And honestly, attack librarian is the platonic ideal of lawyering.

Admit it, your life is better now that you’ve heard attack librarian. You’re welcome.

AtL tipsters are the best, so please connect with her. Feel free to email [her](mailto:kathryn@abovethelaw.com?subject=Your%20Column) with any tips, questions, or comments and follow her on Twitter [@Kathryn1](%E2%80%9C//twitter.com/Kathryn1%22%E2%80%9D) or Mastodon [@Kathryn1@mastodon.social.](//mastodon.social/@Kathryn1%22)

# Family Of Promising Young Biglaw Partner Files Wrongful Death Suit Over Fatal Car Crash
## The complaint alleges that a tractor-trailer driver's negligence was the sole cause of the deadly crash.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onMay 17, 2023 at 1:13 PMMay 17, 2023 at 11:51 AM
10
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/biglaw-partner-wrongful-death-lawsuit/&text=Family%20Of%20Promising%20Young%20Biglaw%20Partner%20Files%20Wrongful%20Death%20Suit%20Over%20Fatal%20Car%20Crash)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/biglaw-partner-wrongful-death-lawsuit/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2023/05/biglaw-partner-wrongful-death-lawsuit/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The family of the late [Harry S. Jackson III](https://www.foxrothschild.com/harry-s-jackson-iii), a young Fox Rothschild partner, has filed a wrongful death lawsuit against tractor-trailer driver, Cheick Yameogo, and the vehicle’s owner, Western Express Inc., for allegedly causing the car crash that killed Jackson through negligence and recklessness.

Jackson was just 33 years old when he died on the PA Turnpike on July 29, 2022, after his car collided with a jackknifed tractor-trailer. Jackson’s untimely death came about one week before he was supposed to get married, and just days before his 34th birthday. “I don’t think an accident like this occurs without reckless conduct,” said Feldman Shepherd co-managing shareholder [Alan Feldman](https://feldmanshepherd.com/attorneys-professionals/alan-feldman/), who is representing the estate.

As noted in the [complaint](https://images.law.com/contrib/content/uploads/documents/402/132957/JacksonV.WesternExpress.pdf), Jackson’s estate is not only bringing wrongful death and survival actions but is also seeking punitive damages. Feldman spoke to the [Legal Intelligencer](https://www.law.com/thelegalintelligencer/2023/05/16/estate-of-fox-rothschild-partner-who-died-in-car-crash-files-wrongful-death-suit/) about Jackson’s premature death, saying, “Everything was in front of him. An amazing life.”

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
“This was clearly a young lawyer who was going places,” Feldman said. “He was enormously respected by his colleagues.” …

Feldman said he did not know Jackson while he was alive but that he has spoken to Jackson’s colleagues at Fox Rothschild. “I’ve never heard anyone described in such glowing terms,” Feldman said.

Prior to his passing, Jackson was involved in Fox Rothschild’s gaming practice and was developing an expertise in e-sports. He’d recently been named co-chair of firm’s American Indian Law practice group, as he was a member of the Nanticoke Lenni-Lenape Tribal Nation who served as an elected member of its nine-member trial council.

“The world was his oyster,” Feldman went on to say. ”Harry’s passing is just a reminder that we’re on this earth for whatever time is allotted to us and that we have to enjoy every day.”

# The Best Way To Score A Biglaw Summer Associate Gig? Save A Partner's Life
## This hero was rewarded -- generously.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 20, 2017 at 12:46 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/the-best-way-to-score-a-biglaw-summer-associate-gig-save-a-partners-life/&text=The%20Best%20Way%20To%20Score%20A%20Biglaw%20Summer%20Associate%20Gig?%20Save%20A%20Partner’s%20Life)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/the-best-way-to-score-a-biglaw-summer-associate-gig-save-a-partners-life/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2017/06/the-best-way-to-score-a-biglaw-summer-associate-gig-save-a-partners-life/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

A law student saved the day.

Last month, we shared with you the tale of a [heroic law student](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/05/who-is-the-mystery-law-student-who-came-to-the-rescue-of-a-biglaw-partner/) who came to the aid of a Biglaw partner who was involved in a violent altercation with some local ruffians.

[John P. Rowley III](http://www.bakermckenzie.com/en/people/r/rowley-iii-john-p/), a partner at [Baker McKenzie](https://abovethelaw.com/law-firms/baker-mckenzie/), shattered his hand and sustained cuts and bruises after being pushed into a departing train and kicked and punched by several teens at the Gallery Place Metro station on May 12. Luckily, GW Law student [Andrew Miller](https://www.linkedin.com/in/andrewmillerlaw/) was just behind Rowley, and ran to his assistance, pulling the teens off of the former federal prosecutor before they could do any more harm. Miller suffered a concussion as a consequence for being a good samaritan. But, this story has a very happy ending for both Rowley and Miller.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
At some point after the attack, Rowley began communicating with Miller, and one week after the assault, Miller found himself with an offer he couldn’t refuse. [Law.com](http://www.law.com/sites/almstaff/2017/06/20/good-samaritan-scores-summer-associate-gig-after-train-station-assault/) has more information on what happened next:


Andrew Miller

Rowley called Miller and offered him a position as a summer associate in the firm’s Washington, D.C., office. Miller … started at the firm on June 12.

“I practiced law for quite a while now and, frankly, natural leaders are hard to find,” Rowley said. “When I met [Miller] and I got to know him a little bit, reflecting back on the courage of jumping in, he was the kind of person that we wanted to have here at the firm this summer.”

Miller was genuinely shocked that Rowley extended an offer to him, but he’s thrilled about working at a firm that was willing to take a chance on someone like him, just because of his unquestionable selflessness and his willingness to step in during an emergency situation when others turned away.

“I’m sure I’ll tell my grandkids about it,” Miller said about his once-in-a-lifetime experience and the resultant job offer. Kindness counts, even in Biglaw.

# 'You Should Be Ashamed Of Yourself': Lady Gaga Sounds Off Against Celebrity Lawyer In Deposition
## This superstar's fiery testimony did not disappoint.
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJanuary 31, 2019 at 3:15 PMJanuary 31, 2019 at 2:50 PM
114

Lady Gaga (Photo by Axelle/Bauer-Griffin/FilmMagic)

As Little Monsters everywhere know, Lady Gaga sure knows how to put on a show, but the fireworks don’t stop once she gets off the stage. According to recently unsealed court documents, the pop singer-turned-actress was deposed in September 2017 as part of singer Kesha’s ongoing legal battle against producer Lukasz “Dr. Luke” Gottwald, and Gaga got into a really fiery exchange with Dr. Luke’s lawyer, [Christine Lepera](https://www.msk.com/attorneys-Christine_Lepera), one of the nation’s top music lawyers.

Before we get into the details, here’s background on the case, from the [Daily Beast](https://www.thedailybeast.com/lady-gaga-lambasts-dr-lukes-lawyer-in-explosive-kesha-deposition):

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
In 2014, Kesha accused Dr. Luke of forcing her to take a date rape drug and then taking advantage of her in a hotel room. He denied the allegation, and Kesha dropped her California suits against him in respect of the allegation in 2016, but other suits continued in New York.

Kesha has claimed that the producer denied her profits from her work including the smash single “Tik Tok.” Dr. Luke, in turn, filed a defamation claim and framed her attempts to get out of the record deal as extortion.

Gaga, whose real name (Stefani Germanotta) appears in the transcript, is a survivor of sexual assault, and her lawyer, Orin Snyder of Gibson Dunn, noted before she began to testify that the deposition served as a “trigger event” for his client. “She has experienced in the past few hours some PTSD reactions which is causing some trauma and emotional reactivity,” Snyder said. “So she is crying now the record will reflect.”

Later on, Gaga described a time when she saw Kesha wearing only her underwear in Dr. Luke’s home studio, and spoke of the singer’s “immense sadness and depression and fear,” saying she seemed “visibly very different than when I had seen her before.” Lepera then asked if Gaga thought Kesha’s rape accusation had damaged Dr. Luke’s reputation. “I made my view of him and his reputation when I saw her in that back room,” she said. “That was an image that—of something that happened to me, and I felt and knew in my heart that she was telling the truth, and I believe her.”

Lepera: “With respect to Mr. Gottwald himself, you have absolutely no personal knowledge or information as to any interaction between him and Ms. Sebert, correct, physical or otherwise?”

Gaga: “Yes, I do have knowledge… She told me he assaulted her.”

When the lawyer asked if her information was based purely on Kesha’s account, Gaga replied: “Well, you know, when men assault women, they don’t invite people over to watch.”

Things went downhill from there, with Gaga issuing an exasperated “oh, ma’am” as Lepera’s line of questioning about her “factual knowledge” of Kesha’s alleged assault continued, unabated. From the [deposition transcript](https://www.scribd.com/document/398569447/Lady-Gaga-s-deposition-in-Dr-Luke-s-defamation-lawsuit):



Lepera kept going, using an awkward example of whether Gaga would automatically believe a victim who had accused her own father of rape. Gaga held steadfast in her testimony in support of Kesha, saying, “I believe her. And I know it to be true.” When Lepera once more asked, “You weren’t there, correct?” that’s when the superstar let loose on the celebrity lawyer, issuing this incredibly fiery response.

####“Don’t you roll your eyes at me. You should be ashamed of yourself.”
Let the record reflect that this may be the first time that a celebrity has uttered such words during a deposition. We would’ve paid good money to be a fly on the wall in the room where this proceeding took place just to see the look on Christine Lepera’s face after Lady Gaga dropped the depo mic like that.

Give this woman an Oscar already.

# From Founding Partner Of A Biglaw Firm To Secretary Of State
## Not a bad career after you've already founded an Am Law 100 firm.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJune 10, 2019 at 6:18 PMJune 10, 2019 at 3:03 PM
17
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/from-founding-partner-of-a-biglaw-firm-to-secretary-of-state/&text=From%20Founding%20Partner%20Of%20A%20Biglaw%20Firm%20To%20Secretary%20Of%20State)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/from-founding-partner-of-a-biglaw-firm-to-secretary-of-state/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/06/from-founding-partner-of-a-biglaw-firm-to-secretary-of-state/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Philander Chase Knox is one of the founding partners of which Biglaw firm, known for early business dealing with noted industrialists Andrew Carnegie, Andrew Mellon, and Henry Clay Frick?

Hint: Knox left the firm for a political career. He went on to serve as Attorney General, U.S. Senator, and Secretary of State.

See the answer on the next page.

# This Biglaw Name Partner Knows A Little Something About The Impeachment Of A President
## Well, isn't that a nifty legal experience?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onJanuary 22, 2019 at 5:31 PMJanuary 22, 2019 at 2:01 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/this-biglaw-name-partner-knows-a-little-something-about-the-impeachment-of-a-president/&text=This%20Biglaw%20Name%20Partner%20Knows%20A%20Little%20Something%20About%20The%20Impeachment%20Of%20A%20President)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/this-biglaw-name-partner-knows-a-little-something-about-the-impeachment-of-a-president/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2019/01/this-biglaw-name-partner-knows-a-little-something-about-the-impeachment-of-a-president/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
The name partner of what Biglaw firm was special counsel to the House Judiciary Committee during the impeachment process initiated against Richard Nixon?

Hint: The Biglaw firm was founded in Chicago in 1914 under a different name than it currently operates under. When it opened it was known as Newman, Poppenhusen & Stern.

See the answer on the next page.

# Which Firms Give In-House Counsel Nightmares? (2017)
## What is it about these firms that strikes fear in the hearts of GCs?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onSeptember 21, 2016 at 12:08 PMSeptember 21, 2016 at 5:42 PM
6
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/which-firms-give-in-house-counsel-nightmares-2017/&text=Which%20Firms%20Give%20In-House%20Counsel%20Nightmares?%20(2017))[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/which-firms-give-in-house-counsel-nightmares-2017/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/09/which-firms-give-in-house-counsel-nightmares-2017/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
What firms do general counsels absolutely, positively not want to face in court? Answering that question is the motivation behind a survey from BTI Consulting Group. They asked 300 general counsels in a free form question which law firms they would least like to see as opposing counsel and compiled their “Fearsome Foursome” list.

So who made the cut this year (in alphabetical order)?

Dentons
Jones Day
Kirkland & Ellis
Skadden Arps Slate Meagher & Flom

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)
### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
Congratulations on your fierceness.

[According to](http://www.law360.com/corporate/articles/841458/the-4-firms-that-strike-fear-in-gcs-) Law360 (sub. req.), turning up on this list is old hat for Jones Day, Kirkland, and Skadden, but brand new territory for Dentons. The addition of Dentons in the “Fearsome Foursome” means Quinn Emanuel lost its seat on this high-powered train.

So what is it about these firms that strikes fear in the hearts of GCs? According to Michael Rynowecer, CEO of BTI Consulting Group, they just don’t give up:

General counsels who responded to the survey pointed to a few things that the four firms named most-feared in the courtroom have in common, the first of which is an unrelenting approach, Rynowecer said.

“They have several strategies in place at once and keep coming at the issue,” he said. “Not only do they overturn every rock, but they find new rocks to overturn and keep coming up with new ways to act in their clients’ interests.”

# Salary Wars Scorecard: Which Firms Have Announced Raises And Bonuses? (2018)
## Where does your law firm stand?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 5, 2018 at 1:46 PMOctober 24, 2018 at 10:04 AM
85
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises-2018/&text=Salary%20Wars%20Scorecard:%20Which%20Firms%20Have%20Announced%20Raises%20And%20Bonuses?%20(2018))[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises-2018/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises-2018/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Since we broke the news of the new $190K salary scale for associates at large law firms in the United States — a trend that was [started by Milbank](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/new-york-to-190k-no-cravath-didnt-make-the-first-move/) on Monday, June 4, 2018 — several firms have fallen in line and matched the scale, but dozens more firms have remained completely silent. Maybe this Above the Law feature will encourage some more firms speak up…

Today, we unveil a table of all of the firms that have already matched the new salary scale, the markets where those matches were made, whether bonuses were offered on top of raises, and the profits per partner (PPP) at those firms for your viewing pleasure. We will be updating this table on a daily basis, sometimes multiple times, as news on raises unfolds. If you see any information here that is incorrect or needs further clarification, let us know.

Remember, we are covering this trend extensively, so please drop us a line — text (646-820-8477) or [email](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Raises%20Salary) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Milbank”) — when you know of another firm making a compensation move. Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file. All sources are kept confidential.

# Millennials – Lazy And Entitled – Tired Of It!
## Managing partner Bruce Stachenfeld comes to the defense of much-maligned millennials.
By [Bruce Stachenfeld](https://abovethelaw.com/author/brucestachenfeld/)  
onOctober 27, 2016 at 6:43 PMOctober 27, 2016 at 3:49 PM
24
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/millennials-lazy-and-entitled-tired-of-it/&text=Millennials%20–%20Lazy%20And%20Entitled%20–%20Tired%20Of%20It!)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/millennials-lazy-and-entitled-tired-of-it/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/10/millennials-lazy-and-entitled-tired-of-it/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Everyone knows that millennials are lazy and entitled – it is common knowledge!

I really hate it when people say that kind of thing. It is just the same sort of stereotyping that you hear about races, religions, and other groups of people. Stereotypes, as we all know so well, don’t just insult people; they are worse than that because they start a harmful cycle of a self-fulfilling prophecy in a negative direction.

It is the opposite of the wise Dale Carnegie’s advice – given close to 100 years ago in his amazing book, [How to Win Friends and Influence People](http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/1508569754/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=390957&creativeASIN=1508569754&linkCode=as2&tag=dealbreaker-20&linkId=V4RF2XZ7VCJ4ULPO) (affiliate link). He says:

[  ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
[Sponsored](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
### [ Legal AI: 3 Steps Law Firms Should Take Now ](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)
If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
“Give a person a fine reputation to live up to.”

Negative stereotypes do the exact opposite.

So for some reason, some people – who I assume are from my amazingly wonderful baby boomer generation — have labeled millennials as lazy and entitled. I have one word to say about that:

“Fiddlesticks.”

###Sponsored
[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/wp-admin/post.php?post=1052766&action=edit)

[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
We all do our best not to fall into traps laid by others and make our own decisions and determinations. As for myself, I am confident in saying that I have personally interacted with a great number of millennials, both in the workplace and in my personal life. Some are indeed lazy and entitled, and some are super-hardworking people who want to set the world on fire. But I don’t see any reason to believe the dispersion between lazy and entitled versus super-hardworking is any different from my (truly extraordinarily wonderful and amazing) baby boomer generation.

And – let’s be honest – what did our parents think of us baby boomers when we were growing up? Didn’t we get the odd butt-kicking to get off our lazy asses and mow the lawn?

Bottom line is that millennials are just people like everyone else. There is absolutely no reason to group them in the first place. However, if you feel the need to group them and come up with some stereotypes for millennials, for heaven’s sake please follow Dale Carnegie’s advice and come up with some good things to say.

This is a bit of a rant – and I am sorry for that – however, I really see something needlessly negative going on, and I think we all have enough to think about and worry about without creating needless troubles for ourselves and others.

Finally, I conclude with a recommendation to read Dale Carnegie’s book. It is a treasure. If you don’t believe me, ask Warren Buffett, who (it was reported in a biography of Buffett) read it over 100 times, and he hasn’t done that badly.

# One Biglaw Exit Strategy Has A Storybook Ending
## This is one way to leave law firm life.
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onApril 5, 2016 at 4:11 PMApril 5, 2016 at 4:11 PM
0
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/one-biglaw-exit-strategy-has-a-storybook-ending/&text=One%20Biglaw%20Exit%20Strategy%20Has%20A%20Storybook%20Ending)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/one-biglaw-exit-strategy-has-a-storybook-ending/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/04/one-biglaw-exit-strategy-has-a-storybook-ending/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Hint: He left law firm life and went on to write over 30 novels including The Collectors, Last Man Standing, and Split Second.

# Magic Circle Firm Makes Bonus Money Magically Appear For Associates
## Abracadabra! It's more money!
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onDecember 12, 2022 at 2:14 PMDecember 12, 2022 at 2:08 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/linklaters-bonus-2022/&text=Magic%20Circle%20Firm%20Makes%20Bonus%20Money%20Magically%20Appear%20For%20Associates)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/linklaters-bonus-2022/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/12/linklaters-bonus-2022/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
This top firm isn’t pulling a rabbit out of a hat for associates today. Instead, the big reveal on this magic trick is more money. Top-rated Magic Circle firm Linklaters is wowing U.S. associates with a brand new bonus match.

It’s a definitely a magical time to be a lawyer at Linklaters. According to U.S. Global Practice Head Tom McGrath, the firm will be handing out bonuses “in line with the New York market.” Here’s what that bonus scale looks like, in case you’ve forgotten:

- Class of 2022: $15,000 (pro-rated)
- Class of 2021: $20,000
- Class of 2020: $30,000
- Class of 2019: $57,500
- Class of 2018: $75,000
- Class of 2017: $90,000
- Class of 2016: $105,000
- Class of 2015+: $115,000
Associates in good standing will receive their cash on December 30. Congratulations on your bonuses, Linklaters associates!

(Flip to the next page to see the full memo from Linklaters.)

Remember everyone, we depend on your tips to stay on top of important bonus updates, so when your firm announces or matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

And if you’d like to sign up for ATL’s Bonus Alerts (which is the alert list we also use for salary announcements), please scroll down and enter your email address in the box below this post. If you previously signed up for the bonus alerts, you don’t need to do anything. You’ll receive an email notification within minutes of each bonus announcement that we publish. Thanks for your help!

[Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/) is a senior editor at Above the Law, where she’s worked since 2011. She’d love to hear from you, so please feel free to [email](mailto:staci@abovethelaw.com) her with any tips, questions, comments, or critiques. You can follow her on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/stacizaretsky) or connect with her on [LinkedIn](https://www.linkedin.com/in/staci-zaretsky).

# Washington-Based International Law Firm Raises Salaries Accordingly
## Another big firm matches the market.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onJune 23, 2016 at 4:41 PMJune 23, 2016 at 5:00 PM
35
Shares[](http://twitter.com/share?url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/washington-based-international-law-firm-raises-salaries-accordingly/&text=Washington-Based%20International%20Law%20Firm%20Raises%20Salaries%20Accordingly)[](http://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/washington-based-international-law-firm-raises-salaries-accordingly/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](http://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=http://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/washington-based-international-law-firm-raises-salaries-accordingly/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Another firm has matched the Cravath scale, which we probably would have known earlier if it weren’t one of the famously [anti-email](https://abovethelaw.com/2015/06/biglaw-trend-alert-say-goodbye-to-gmail/) firms. UPDATE (6/23/16 4:59 p.m.): Huh? Apparently after much backlash, the firm didn’t actually ban Gmail. Good to know.

Nah. I’m just kidding… no one emails us from their desktops in the age of smartphones any more.

In any event, we’re happy to report that Steptoe & Johnson LLP has issued associate raises! We’re awaiting confirmation on which offices are implicated in the raise — Steptoe is in D.C., New York, Chicago, Los Angeles, Palo Alto, and Phoenix — but at least the biggest market lawyers are seeing the boost. UPDATE (6/23/16 4:54 p.m.): Phoenix is on a different scale, but they are apparently getting some smaller raise too.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Steptoe operates a little differently than most firms. Rather than issuing raises strictly by Class, Steptoe works a little [more like Baker Botts](https://abovethelaw.com/2016/06/saturday-morning-special-another-firm-raises-compensation-but-do-they-beat-the-market/), with multiple “tiers” of seniority. But unlike Baker Botts — who topped out at $305K — Steptoe is topping out at the more mainstream $315K. So we can call this a “Cravath match” even though the structure is a little unorthodox.

The raise is, like most of these raises, effective on July 1 and includes the summer associates.

Now, the real question is: will [Steptoe & Johnson](http://www.steptoe-johnson.com) match the [Steptoe & Johnson](http://www.steptoe.com) scale?[1]

Remember, when your firm matches, please text us (646-820-8477) or [email us](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com?subject=%5BFirm%20Name%5D%20Matches%20Cravath) (subject line: “[Firm Name] Matches Cravath”). Please include the memo if available. You can take a photo of the memo and send it via text or email if you don’t want to forward the original PDF or Word file.

# Morning Docket: 06.06.18
## * Simpson Thacher isn't increasing associate salaries to the $190K scale (yet), but it is partnering with Columbia Business School to launch a new associate training program. We bet your incoming associates are "STBReady" ... for higher salaries. Click [here](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises-2018/) to see all the firms that have raised salaries thus far . [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/06/05/simpson-thacher-launches-new-associate-training-program/)] * President Trump is appealing the decision that says he can't block people on Twitter based on their political views to the Second Circuit (because of course he is). He already had to unblock the seven plaintiffs in the case, and he likely wasn't very happy about it because of glorious follow-up tweets like [this](https://twitter.com/rpbp/status/1003800553351274496?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.buzzfeed.com%2Fbriannasacks%2Ftrump-twitter-block-appeal). [[BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeed.com/briannasacks/trump-twitter-block-appeal?utm_term=.mcYBzMn5k#.dcD0X92nW)] * After reportedly being rejected by several candidates for the associate attorney general position -- one that would oversee the Mueller investigation if Rod Rosenstein were to suddenly depart -- the Trump Administration is giving up on trying to fill the job for the moment, and focusing on other vacancies. [[Wall Street Journal](https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-administration-sidelines-effort-to-appoint-justice-department-no-3-1528208396)] * In the wake of allegations of sexual harassment against former Ninth Circuit Judge Alex Kozinski, the federal judiciary's working group on sexual harassment has released 24 recommendations, specifying three areas that need change to make circuit courts an "exemplary workplace." [[Big Law Business](https://biglawbusiness.com/sex-harassment-working-group-in-judiciary-releases-findings/)] * The American Bar Association wants out of this whistleblower suit, ASAP. ABA officials claim that former Charlotte Law professor Barbara Bernier only added the law school regulatory group to her suit against the defunct law school and its owner, InfiLaw, as a "last-ditch effort" to keep her action kicking in court. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/2018/06/05/aba-says-charlotte-law-whistleblower-suit-is-last-ditch-effort/)]
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 6, 2018 at 8:29 AMJune 5, 2018 at 9:58 PM
1
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/morning-docket-06-06-18/&text=Morning%20Docket:%2006.06.18)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/morning-docket-06-06-18/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/morning-docket-06-06-18/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

Click [here](https://abovethelaw.com/2018/06/salary-wars-scorecard-which-firms-have-announced-raises-2018/) to see all the firms that have raised salaries thus far . [[New York Law Journal](https://www.law.com/americanlawyer/2018/06/05/simpson-thacher-launches-new-associate-training-program/)]

* President Trump is appealing the decision that says he can’t block people on Twitter based on their political views to the Second Circuit (because of course he is). He already had to unblock the seven plaintiffs in the case, and he likely wasn’t very happy about it because of glorious follow-up tweets like [this](https://twitter.com/rpbp/status/1003800553351274496?ref_src=twsrc%5Etfw&ref_url=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.buzzfeed.com%2Fbriannasacks%2Ftrump-twitter-block-appeal). [[BuzzFeed](https://www.buzzfeed.com/briannasacks/trump-twitter-block-appeal?utm_term=.mcYBzMn5k#.dcD0X92nW)]

* After reportedly being rejected by several candidates for the associate attorney general position — one that would oversee the Mueller investigation if Rod Rosenstein were to suddenly depart — the Trump Administration is giving up on trying to fill the job for the moment, and focusing on other vacancies. [[Wall Street Journal](https://www.wsj.com/articles/trump-administration-sidelines-effort-to-appoint-justice-department-no-3-1528208396)]

# Morning Docket: 02.15.18
## * A white substance sent to Stanford Law School turned out to be harmless, but the school remains concerned based an accompanying threat. [[Stanford University News](https://news.stanford.edu/2018/02/14/incident-law-school-resolved/)] * This prolonged malaise in the legal sector? Yeah, that's not normal. [[Law.com](https://www.law.com/sites/ali/2018/02/14/why-are-law-firm-growing-so-slowly-the-answer-may-be-fairly-straightforward/)] * Fifth Circuit agrees that the bail system employed in the Houston area is unconstitutional. But, you know, didn't go so far as to actually release anybody. [[Courthouse News Service](https://www.courthousenews.com/fifth-circuit-affirms-unconstitutionality-of-harris-county-bail-system/)] * Selendy & Gay opens for business today after striking out on their own from Quinn Emanuel. [[American Lawyer](https://www.law.com/sites/americanlawyer/2018/02/15/selendy-gay-launches-with-quinn-emanuel-expats/)] * Playboy's suit against Boing Boing -- which sounds funnier than it is -- was dismissed for failing to state a copyright claim. Playboy had sued Boing Boing for reporting on a website that contained copyrighted material in a certainly felt like a wild overreach. [[EFF](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2018/02/court-dismisses-playboys-lawsuit-against-boing-boing-now)] * Partner's son admits to embezzling $827K from firm. Whenever one of these office manager embezzling stories comes up I'm always left wondering how people manage to miss the first $826,999.
By [Joe Patrice](https://abovethelaw.com/author/joe-patrice/)  
onFebruary 15, 2018 at 8:27 AM
1

# David Boies Isn't Worried About Recent Scrutiny
## What? Me Worry?
By [Kathryn Rubino](https://abovethelaw.com/author/krubino/)  
onDecember 7, 2017 at 6:03 PMOctober 22, 2018 at 4:35 PM
4
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/david-boies-isnt-worried-about-recent-scrutiny/&text=David%20Boies%20Isn’t%20Worried%20About%20Recent%20Scrutiny)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/david-boies-isnt-worried-about-recent-scrutiny/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2017/12/david-boies-isnt-worried-about-recent-scrutiny/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))

David Boies

I do think that many clients’ perspectives are different and more sophisticated than the public narratives. They understand what lawyers do.

— David Boies, in a [recent interview](https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-12-07/the-superstar-lawyer-tied-to-harvey-weinstein-and-charlie-rose-isn-t-panicked) with Bloomberg, commenting that he doesn’t believe his recent spate of [bad publicity](https://abovethelaw.com/tag/david-boies/) will hurt the firm. The firm’s general counsel, Nick Gravante Jr., also went on to say the chance of losing a major client’s business over the allegations is “zero percent.” I suppose Boies Schiller is large enough that the [New York Times’s legal work](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/new-york-times-fires-david-boies-over-the-whole-grave-betrayal-thing/) and a [chance to challenge Citizens United](https://abovethelaw.com/2017/11/david-boies-loses-more-work-over-weinstein-debacle/) isn’t big league enough to count in Gravante’s book.

###Sponsored

# Top 50 Biglaw Firm Tells Partners Not To Interrupt Associate Vacations With Work Demands
## Do partners at your Biglaw firm respect associates' vacations and time off?
By [Staci Zaretsky](https://abovethelaw.com/author/staci-zaretsky/)  
onJune 10, 2022 at 12:42 PMJune 10, 2022 at 11:58 AM
25
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/top-50-biglaw-firm-tells-partners-not-to-interrupt-associate-vacations-with-work-demands/&text=Top%2050%20Biglaw%20Firm%20Tells%20Partners%20Not%20To%20Interrupt%20Associate%20Vacations%20With%20Work%20Demands)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/top-50-biglaw-firm-tells-partners-not-to-interrupt-associate-vacations-with-work-demands/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/top-50-biglaw-firm-tells-partners-not-to-interrupt-associate-vacations-with-work-demands/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
Biglaw associates know all too well that their vacations and time off may be derailed by partner requests to complete client work. But with a relatively hot lateral market and a new focus on attorney health and wellness, things can change very quickly when lawyers are able to vote with their feet.

Take, for example, what’s happening at Mayer Brown’s London outpost. As first reported by [RollOnFriday](https://www.rollonfriday.com/news-content/mayer-brown-orders-partners-not-ruin-lawyers-holidays), the office’s managing partner, Dominic Griffiths, has instructed partners not to impede upon associates’ vacations with new assignments and work demands. Specifically, Griffiths told partners “there is a presumption that holidays will not be cancelled or interrupted unless there is a genuine emergency which cannot be resolved without the input of the individual concerned.” Here’s more from ROF:

Griffiths [said] he reinforced his reminder with a message to fee earners, telling then that an interruption of their annual leave “only ever happens where there is a genuine emergency which cannot be resolved without your input”. …

[A] spokesperson for Mayer Brown said Griffiths was “simply reiterating the importance of people having a real break from work whilst on holiday, which is largely followed already, and letting the associates know that a work/life balance is one of his priorities”.

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
### [ Navigating Financial Success by Avoiding Common Pitfalls and Maximizing Firm Performance ](https://abovethelaw.com/?sponsored_content=navigating-financial-success-by-avoiding-common-pitfalls-and-maximizing-firm-performance)
In this CLE-eligible webinar, we’ll explore the most common accounting pitfalls and how to avoid them for your firm.
From Pilot and Above The Law  
Griffiths went on to tell ROF, “I believe it is incumbent upon us that client matters are always appropriately covered whilst our lawyers take well deserved breaks in the ordinary course.”

Vacations matter at Mayer Brown, but what about at your Biglaw firm? Please let us know if partners are considerate of associates’ time off, or if they continue to pile on the work regardless of whether or not attorneys are on the clock. Contact us via text at (646) 820-8477 or email at [tips@abovethelaw.com](mailto:tips@abovethelaw.com).

# Victory Laps, Pleading Guilty, The Economy, And Watergate
## Those who remember the Great Recession will also remember what a toll it took on the legal profession.
By [Jill Switzer](https://abovethelaw.com/author/jillswitzer/)  
onJune 16, 2022 at 5:34 PMJune 16, 2022 at 3:39 PM
3
Shares[](https://twitter.com/share?url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/victory-laps-pleading-guilty-the-economy-and-watergate/&text=Victory%20Laps,%20Pleading%20Guilty,%20The%20Economy,%20And%20Watergate)[](https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/victory-laps-pleading-guilty-the-economy-and-watergate/&display=popup&ref=plugin&src=share_button)[](https://www.linkedin.com/shareArticle?mini=true&url=https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/victory-laps-pleading-guilty-the-economy-and-watergate/)[](javascript:void("#ea-share-count-email"))
A lawyer crowed about defending a wrongful death case. In the abstract, there’s nothing wrong about being proud about winning a case. That’s what we do. Unfortunately for him, his celebratory remarks ended up on social media. That drew objections to the remarks from other lawyers, and so, now the lawyer is [eating that crow](https://enewspaper.latimes.com/desktop/latimes/default.aspx?token=42e23962a5d74614be16bae3d62d13e7&utm_id=58114&sfmc_id=304074&edid=a61e54e0-b9b0-4e80-995a-41ef74e668e8).

The death certificate and the coroner’s report said that the decedent had died from a combination of sepsis and an incorrectly placed feeding tube, but the lawyer for the physician who had inserted the tube argued to the jury to ignore the death certificate and ignore the coroner’s findings. He claimed that other hospital staff had contributed to the death, there were other causes, and the case was a “cash grab.”

When the video hit social media, a backlash ensued. Did the lawyer trick the jury into telling it to disregard the evidence? We tell juries all the time to disregard evidence in favor of other evidence, but here, [the evidence of the cause of death](https://mobile.twitter.com/TheTorthub/status/1526761105657417734) was unchallenged.  What do you think about this lawyer’s post-judgment behavior? Is this just another example of the “win at any cost” mentality that permeates our profession (and the larger world)?

[  ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
[Sponsored](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
### [ Is The Future Of Law Distributed? Lessons From The Tech Adoption Curve ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/is-the-future-of-law-distributed-lessons-from-the-tech-adoption-curve/)
The rise of remote work has dramatically reshaped the relationship between Lawyers and Law Firms, see how Scale LLP has taken the steps to get…
From [The Team at Scale LLP](https://bit.ly/3HUNY6c)  
Unanswered questions for me: was the physician the only one sued? Hard to imagine. What about the hospital itself and “other medical staff” that the defense attorney claimed bore responsibility? Regardless, the victory lap that this lawyer took, which went viral, was not a good look for the profession. Yes, he apologized (would he really have done so if the video had remained private?) but the damage had been done. Another hit to lawyer reputations. The public doesn’t understand that litigation, unless settled, is a zero-sum game: one side wins, the other loses. (Do we tell the clients that? I wonder.) I am sure that there are many other similar victory laps, both for plaintiff and defense, but the moral here is to keep them sub rosa.

Michael Avenatti has [changed his mind](https://apnews.com/article/california-santa-ana-michael-avenatti-government-and-politics-260b50d89fff090ab818e61036786512) (even lawyers do that) and now wants to plead guilty to charges in the pending retrial of his case in Orange County, in which he stands accused of, among other things, multiple counts of embezzlement of client funds. However, it’s unclear as to what charges he would plead to and whether the government would agree.

Do you think that the several years of employees being able to negotiate working conditions in the COVID-19 world will come to a screeching halt? Now that we are officially in bear market land, it’s anyone’s guess as to whether those advantages will continue. Are layoffs a harbinger?

One firm that had intended to merge now finds itself in the unhappy position of having to [lay off staff, including lawyers](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/law-firm-lays-off-10-of-all-timekeepers-due-to-decrease-in-demand/). The layoffs are a 10% whack of the workforce. If there is indeed an oversupply of lawyers and an undersupply of work, and that is to be determined, some rethinking may well be looming. Unfortunately, history does have a way of repeating itself, and those who remember the Great Recession will also remember what a toll it took on the legal profession: the dearth of hiring, especially new admittees, and lots of layoffs.

### [ The Business Case For AI At Your Law Firm ](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/) 
ChatGPT ushers in the age of generative AI – even for law firms.
From [THOMSON REUTERS](https://abovethelaw.com/2024/04/the-business-case-for-ai-at-your-law-firm/)  
In the past decade, since the end of the Great Recession, lawyer population has increased by [more than six percent](https://abovethelaw.com/2022/06/yup-the-number-of-lawyers-in-the-country-is-only-going-up/2/). Will the bear market be able to keep lawyers busy and billing? Or will clients and lawyers be looking for spare change under the sofa cushions?

As an old lady lawyer, I remember the [Watergate hearings in 1973](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Watergate_scandal) and watched them gavel to gavel as I awaited starting law school that fall. I was glued to the television, which, aside from movie screens, was the only screen we had back then.

I remember Sam Ervin, the senior senator from North Carolina, the chair of the select Senate committee holding hearings to investigate Watergate. Ervin’s bushy eyebrows, his “country lawyer” demeanor, along with his pocket copy of the U.S. Constitution that he always had by his side, remain [indelible images](https://video.search.yahoo.com/yhs/search;_ylt=Awr.ziXThapiskcBQa42nIlQ?p=senator+sam+ervin+watergate&hsimp=yhs-1&hspart=iba&type=yzpr_9600_CHW_US&param1=WGtbxNcgXOCxgl6lCYo66g%3D%3D&param2=9dUI1n2R0BLDxNuWfiP4aSFOTltNdSPoIx38%2BUf%2FiXrvPdoGmStdlfwLFZYDvqkAJrWWk4yNReCLnBD%2FqPsDZd7olTZcV8HMx1G%2Fk786sE2Tis1g8dJd8zxVWs%2BbKztBnq1TfqUiqPYK9pXifXmJFyorDuCsYXJE71Y6G5tfejAsA0Lsu%2BhSnWhyvR8yxg3FZCgtpQdgsgtFBnqC22qw1kTymId7s0QOsIR%2Bw2n%2F3dM6gJP6oiGzPK8bOuVj20XrIYfdXMbi80m4ClgQPq0IseWOEe45FnO9KbLuWSk332SygCKS8dH%2BJdJ3HNL9yvwn0We11Bs2SoLjgoiAVizuWQ%3D%3D&param3=NwVEMR%2FzKcG52XsVBYEh2%2B7y7tP1R8GKaAIj3YL4xdcsiwgo%2BWEenOKOsmHPG3e8jIvYdjiny1tsf8Kj9W8%2BWlxz2G2CDKLjrAgrDuj%2F80aDj1%2BlX3f96wnQ2vw6i5%2BobvQdqHpM%2B5oK9V7KzQ3c%2F9Hm%2BMBVaFK7ELh37Ou4AhYAB03xoQ8hu8L0JoE%2BuEZXzqOO0qv1FkhOm5cAopUJXEQ7fqInKFX%2FzjWHn%2BsB%2BIBRubOh419AENjo4JkxnJbapBt%2BLZ6b%2FhewdYl5YlUKilrsF3ZPokOsZj%2FYJfZLM37RbUT9XE9N6HMLzFNp04DNXeL6VybWzbVvF0zYXeKRM1jeeSDDwQddAYHY5kxaiCrLGA4q4MCI6z4AqEZ2Lmswsey0lauogxrWIq%2BEDQhn7o5S7kAVpZrLl%2B8UX7Czilpi6LSG%2F7EUDKS5jnsgco77tob2gKvOQOB%2B7B5AYnb7sXv2uuUwWyPImhtGvmE3QcXv9iwXn75ZIW8HA8nKw0Y8aK4Roe5uymw3dBJVFxrJySl5fuigiOvEt0Oz%2FGseBhI%3D&param4=68T1ArA0cLrF%2FboU2XqSKL457KVaDWChmxwFAGC3MO0%3D&fr=yhs-iba-1&fr2=p%3As%2Cv%3Ai%2Cm%3Apivot#id=9&vid=fc7e3635954ed98e680a693773aa598e&action=view).  His “country lawyer” façade hid a mind of breathtaking sharpness and made me even more convinced that I had made the right choice to go to law school.

I remember a young John Dean, testifying that he told President Nixon and his two henchmen, Bob Haldeman and John Ehrlichman, that there was a “cancer on the presidency.”

I remember Alexander Butterfield, whose testimony drove the stake into the heart of the Nixon presidency: the existence of Oval Office tape recordings that proved, beyond a reasonable doubt, that Nixon was at the heart of a both a conspiracy and a coverup.

If 2023 introduced legal professionals to generative AI, then 2024 will be when law firms start adapting to utilize it. Things are moving fast, so…
From [LexisNexis](https://bit.ly/3x7bHOy)  
I remember Judge John Sirica, who ruled that the tapes had to be turned over to the Committee, that there was no executive privilege that attached, and I remember the Burger Supreme Court that upheld unanimously Sirica’s decision. Convictions of a number of lawyers in the Nixon administration led to the almost instant institution of an ethics portion of the general bar exam, at least here in California.

Although Watergate grew out of a third-rate burglary, it gave rise to a constitutional crisis in a nation already racked by war, assassinations, racism, inflation, and other traumas. We have been living in an age of trauma ever since. Almost 50 years after Watergate, what and who will we remember from the House January 6 Committee hearings about the events of January 6, 2021?

Jill Switzer has been an active member of the State Bar of California for over 40 years. She remembers practicing law in a kinder, gentler time. She’s had a diverse legal career, including stints as a deputy district attorney, a solo practice, and several senior in-house gigs. She now mediates full-time, which gives her the opportunity to see dinosaurs, millennials, and those in-between interact — it’s not always civil. You can reach her by email at [oldladylawyer@gmail.com](mailto:oldladylawyer@gmail.com?subject=Your%20ATL%20column).

####Topics
